Query: 0-dimensional biomaterials show inductive properties. Query: Auditory entrainment is strengthened when people see congruent visual and auditory information. Document: UNLABELLED Congruent audiovisual speech enhances our ability to comprehend a speaker, even in noise-free conditions. Relevant:
Query: Auditory entrainment is strengthened when people see congruent visual and auditory information. Document: When incongruent auditory and visual information is presented concurrently, it can hinder a listener's perception and even cause him or her to perceive information that was not presented in either modality. Relevant:
Query: Auditory entrainment is strengthened when people see congruent visual and auditory information. Document: Efforts to investigate the neural basis of these effects have often focused on the special case of discrete audiovisual syllables that are spatially and temporally congruent, with less work done on the case of natural, continuous speech. Relevant:
Query: Auditory entrainment is strengthened when people see congruent visual and auditory information. Document: Recent electrophysiological studies have demonstrated that cortical response measures to continuous auditory speech can be easily obtained using multivariate analysis methods. Relevant:
Query: Auditory entrainment is strengthened when people see congruent visual and auditory information. Document: Here, we apply such methods to the case of audiovisual speech and, importantly, present a novel framework for indexing multisensory integration in the context of continuous speech. Relevant:
Query: Auditory entrainment is strengthened when people see congruent visual and auditory information. Document: Specifically, we examine how the temporal and contextual congruency of ongoing audiovisual speech affects the cortical encoding of the speech envelope in humans using electroencephalography. Relevant:
Query: Auditory entrainment is strengthened when people see congruent visual and auditory information. Document: We demonstrate that the cortical representation of the speech envelope is enhanced by the presentation of congruent audiovisual speech in noise-free conditions. Relevant:
Query: Auditory entrainment is strengthened when people see congruent visual and auditory information. Document: Furthermore, we show that this is likely attributable to the contribution of neural generators that are not particularly active during unimodal stimulation and that it is most prominent at the temporal scale corresponding to syllabic rate (2-6 Hz). Relevant:
Query: Auditory entrainment is strengthened when people see congruent visual and auditory information. Document: Finally, our data suggest that neural entrainment to the speech envelope is inhibited when the auditory and visual streams are incongruent both temporally and contextually. Relevant:
Query: Auditory entrainment is strengthened when people see congruent visual and auditory information. Document: SIGNIFICANCE STATEMENT Seeing a speaker's face as he or she talks can greatly help in understanding what the speaker is saying. Relevant:
Query: Auditory entrainment is strengthened when people see congruent visual and auditory information. Document: This is because the speaker's facial movements relay information about what the speaker is saying, but also, importantly, when the speaker is saying it. Relevant:
Query: Auditory entrainment is strengthened when people see congruent visual and auditory information. Document: Studying how the brain uses this timing relationship to combine information from continuous auditory and visual speech has traditionally been methodologically difficult. Relevant:
Query: Auditory entrainment is strengthened when people see congruent visual and auditory information. Document: Here we introduce a new approach for doing this using relatively inexpensive and noninvasive scalp recordings. Relevant:
Query: Auditory entrainment is strengthened when people see congruent visual and auditory information. Document: Specifically, we show that the brain's representation of auditory speech is enhanced when the accompanying visual speech signal shares the same timing. Relevant:
Query: Auditory entrainment is strengthened when people see congruent visual and auditory information. Document: Furthermore, we show that this enhancement is most pronounced at a time scale that corresponds to mean syllable length. Relevant:
Query: Auditory entrainment is strengthened when people see congruent visual and auditory information. Document: During continuous speech, lip movements provide visual temporal signals that facilitate speech processing. Relevant:
Query: Auditory entrainment is strengthened when people see congruent visual and auditory information. Document: Here, using MEG we directly investigated how these visual signals interact with rhythmic brain activity in participants listening to and seeing the speaker. Relevant:
Query: Auditory entrainment is strengthened when people see congruent visual and auditory information. Document: First, we investigated coherence between oscillatory brain activity and speaker's lip movements and demonstrated significant entrainment in visual cortex. Relevant:
Query: Auditory entrainment is strengthened when people see congruent visual and auditory information. Document: We then used partial coherence to remove contributions of the coherent auditory speech signal from the lip-brain coherence. Relevant:
Query: Auditory entrainment is strengthened when people see congruent visual and auditory information. Document: Comparing this synchronization between different attention conditions revealed that attending visual speech enhances the coherence between activity in visual cortex and the speaker's lips. Relevant:
Query: Auditory entrainment is strengthened when people see congruent visual and auditory information. Document: Further, we identified a significant partial coherence between left motor cortex and lip movements and this partial coherence directly predicted comprehension accuracy. Relevant:
Query: Auditory entrainment is strengthened when people see congruent visual and auditory information. Document: Our results emphasize the importance of visually entrained and attention-modulated rhythmic brain activity for the enhancement of audiovisual speech processing. Relevant:
Query: Auditory entrainment is strengthened when people see congruent visual and auditory information. Document: The human ability to continuously track dynamic environmental stimuli, in particular speech, is proposed to profit from "entrainment" of endogenous neural oscillations, which involves phase reorganization such that "optimal" phase comes into line with temporally expected critical events, resulting in improved processing. Relevant:
Query: Auditory entrainment is strengthened when people see congruent visual and auditory information. Document: The current experiment goes beyond previous work in this domain by addressing two thus far unanswered questions. Relevant:
Query: Auditory entrainment is strengthened when people see congruent visual and auditory information. Document: First, how general is neural entrainment to environmental rhythms: Can neural oscillations be entrained by temporal dynamics of ongoing rhythmic stimuli without abrupt onsets? Relevant:
Query: Auditory entrainment is strengthened when people see congruent visual and auditory information. Document: Second, does neural entrainment optimize performance of the perceptual system: Does human auditory perception benefit from neural phase reorganization? Relevant:
Query: Auditory entrainment is strengthened when people see congruent visual and auditory information. Document: In a human electroencephalography study, listeners detected short gaps distributed uniformly with respect to the phase angle of a 3-Hz frequency-modulated stimulus. Relevant:
Query: Auditory entrainment is strengthened when people see congruent visual and auditory information. Document: Listeners' ability to detect gaps in the frequency-modulated sound was not uniformly distributed in time, but clustered in certain preferred phases of the modulation. Relevant:
Query: Auditory entrainment is strengthened when people see congruent visual and auditory information. Document: Moreover, the optimal stimulus phase was individually determined by the neural delta oscillation entrained by the stimulus. Relevant:
Query: Auditory entrainment is strengthened when people see congruent visual and auditory information. Document: Finally, delta phase predicted behavior better than stimulus phase or the event-related potential after the gap. Relevant:
Query: Auditory entrainment is strengthened when people see congruent visual and auditory information. Document: This study demonstrates behavioral benefits of phase realignment in response to frequency-modulated auditory stimuli, overall suggesting that frequency fluctuations in natural environmental input provide a pacing signal for endogenous neural oscillations, thereby influencing perceptual processing. Document: Also, during the 1-year follow-up, combined analysis of MSC-treated groups revealed significantly decreased risk of opportunistic infections than the control group (hazard ratio, 0.42; 95% CI, 0.20-0.85, P=.02)   CONCLUSION Among patients undergoing renal transplant, the use of autologous MSCs compared with anti-IL-2 receptor antibody induction therapy resulted in lower incidence of acute rejection, decreased risk of opportunistic infection, and better estimated renal function at 1 year. Query: Autologous transplantation of mesenchymal stem cells causes fewer opportunistic infections than induction therapy with anti-interleukin-2 receptor antibodies. Document: The 1-year incidence of SAEs was 33.3% (n = 5) in the allogeneic group and 53.3% (n = 8) in the autologous group (P = .46). Relevant:

Document: At 1 year, there were no ventricular arrhythmia SAEs observed among allogeneic recipients compared with 4 patients (26.7%) in the autologous group (P = .10). Relevant:

Query: Autologous transplantation of mesenchymal stem cells has lower rates of rejection than induction therapy with anti-interleukin-2 receptor antibodies. Document: After 6 months, 4 of 53 patients (7.5%) in the autologous MSC plus standard-dose CNI group (95% CI, 0.4%-14.7%; P = .04) and 4 of 52 patients (7.7%) in the low-dose group (95% CI, 0.5%-14.9%; P = .046) compared with 11 of 51 controls (21.6%; 95% CI, 10.5%-32.6%) had biopsy-confirmed acute rejection. Query: Autologous transplantation of mesenchymal stem cells has lower rates of rejection than induction therapy with anti-interleukin-2 receptor antibodies. Relevant:
Query: Autologous transplantation of mesenchymal stem cells has lower rates of rejection than induction therapy with anti-interleukin-2 receptor antibodies. Document: Also, during the 1-year follow-up, combined analysis of MSC-treated groups revealed significantly decreased risk of opportunistic infections than the control group (hazard ratio, 0.42; 95% CI, 0.20-0.85, P=.02)   CONCLUSION Among patients undergoing renal transplant, the use of autologous MSCs compared with anti-IL-2 receptor antibody induction therapy resulted in lower incidence of acute rejection, decreased risk of opportunistic infection, and better estimated renal function at 1 year. Query: Autophagy declines in aged organisms. Document: Chaperone-mediated autophagy (CMA), a selective mechanism for degradation of cytosolic proteins in lysosomes, contributes to the removal of altered proteins as part of the cellular quality-control systems. Relevant:
Query: Autophagy declines in aged organisms. Document: We have previously found that CMA activity declines in aged organisms and have proposed that this failure in cellular clearance could contribute to the accumulation of altered proteins, the abnormal cellular homeostasis and, eventually, the functional loss characteristic of aged organisms. Relevant:
Query: Autophagy declines in aged organisms. Document: To determine whether these negative features of aging can be prevented by maintaining efficient autophagic activity until late in life, in this work we have corrected the CMA defect in aged rodents. Relevant:
Query: Autophagy declines in aged organisms. Document: We have generated a double transgenic mouse model in which the amount of the lysosomal receptor for CMA, previously shown to decrease in abundance with age, can be modulated. Relevant:
Query: Autophagy declines in aged organisms. Document: We have analyzed in this model the consequences of preventing the age-dependent decrease in receptor abundance in aged rodents at the cellular and organ levels. Relevant:
Query: Autophagy declines in aged organisms. Document: We show here that CMA activity is maintained until advanced ages if the decrease in the receptor abundance is prevented and that preservation of autophagic activity is associated with lower intracellular accumulation of damaged proteins, better ability to handle protein damage and improved organ function. Relevant:
Query: Autophagy declines in aged organisms. Document: The ability to maintain a functional proteome, or proteostasis, declines during the ageing process. Relevant:
Query: Autophagy declines in aged organisms. Document: Damaged and misfolded proteins accumulate with age, impairing cell function and tissue homeostasis. Relevant:
Query: Autophagy declines in aged organisms. Document: The accumulation of damaged proteins contributes to multiple age-related diseases such as Alzheimer's, Parkinson's or Huntington's disease. Relevant:
Query: Autophagy declines in aged organisms. Document: Damaged proteins are degraded by the ubiquitin-proteasome system or through autophagy-lysosome, key components of the proteostasis network. Relevant:
Query: Autophagy declines in aged organisms. Document: Modulation of either proteasome activity or autophagic-lysosomal potential extends lifespan and protects organisms from symptoms associated with proteostasis disorders, suggesting that protein clearance mechanisms are directly linked to ageing and age-associated diseases. Relevant:
Query: Autophagy declines in aged organisms. Document: Liver is a vital organ with many important functions, and the maintenance of normal hepatic function is necessary for health. Relevant:
Query: Autophagy declines in aged organisms. Document: As an essential mechanism for maintaining cellular homeostasis, autophagy plays an important role in ensuring normal organ function. Relevant:
Query: Autophagy declines in aged organisms. Document: Studies have indicated that the degeneration of hepatic function is associated with autophagic deficiency in aging liver. Relevant:
Query: Autophagy declines in aged organisms. Document: However, the underlying mechanisms still remain unclear. Relevant:
Query: Autophagy declines in aged organisms. Document: The serine protease Omi/HtrA2 belongs to the HtrA family and promotes apoptosis through either the caspase-dependent or caspase-independent pathway. Relevant:
Query: Autophagy declines in aged organisms. Document: Mice lacking Omi/HtrA2 exhibited progeria symptoms (premature aging), which were similar to the characteristics of autophagic insufficiency. Relevant:
Query: Autophagy declines in aged organisms. Document: In this study, we demonstrated that both the protein level of Omi/HtrA2 in liver and hepatic function were reduced as rats aged, and there was a positive correlation between them. Relevant:
Query: Autophagy declines in aged organisms. Document: Furthermore, several autophagy-related proteins (LC3II/I, Beclin-1 and LAMP2) in rat liver were decreased significantly with the increasing of age. Relevant:
Query: Autophagy declines in aged organisms. Document: Finally, inhibition of Omi/HtrA2 resulted in reduced autophagy and hepatic dysfunction. Relevant:
Query: Autophagy declines in aged organisms. Document: In conclusion, these results suggest that Omi/HtrA2 participates in age-related autophagic deficiency in rat liver. Relevant:
Query: Autophagy declines in aged organisms. Document: This study may offer a novel insight into the mechanism involved in liver aging. Relevant:
Query: Bariatric surgery has a positive impact on mental health. Document: IMPORTANCE Bariatric surgery is associated with sustained weight loss and improved physical health status for severely obese individuals. Relevant:
Query: Bariatric surgery has a positive impact on mental health. Document: Mental health conditions may be common among patients seeking bariatric surgery; however, the prevalence of these conditions and whether they are associated with postoperative outcomes remains unknown. Relevant:
Query: Bariatric surgery has a positive impact on mental health. Document: OBJECTIVE To determine the prevalence of mental health conditions among bariatric surgery candidates and recipients, to evaluate the association between preoperative mental health conditions and health outcomes following bariatric surgery, and to evaluate the association between surgery and the clinical course of mental health conditions. Relevant:
Query: Bariatric surgery has a positive impact on mental health. Document: DATA SOURCES We searched PubMed, MEDLINE on OVID, and PsycINFO for studies published between January 1988 and November 2015. Relevant:
Query: Bariatric surgery has a positive impact on mental health. Document: Study quality was assessed using an adapted tool for risk of bias; quality of evidence was rated based on GRADE (Grading of Recommendations Assessment, Development and Evaluation) criteria. Relevant:
Query: Bariatric surgery has a positive impact on mental health. Document: FINDINGS We identified 68 publications meeting inclusion criteria: 59 reporting the prevalence of preoperative mental health conditions (65,363 patients) and 27 reporting associations between preoperative mental health conditions and postoperative outcomes (50,182 patients). Relevant:
Query: Bariatric surgery has a positive impact on mental health. Document: Among patients seeking and undergoing bariatric surgery, the most common mental health conditions, based on random-effects estimates of prevalence, were depression (19% [95% CI, 14%-25%]) and binge eating disorder (17% [95% CI, 13%-21%]). Relevant:
Query: Bariatric surgery has a positive impact on mental health. Document: There was conflicting evidence regarding the association between preoperative mental health conditions and postoperative weight loss. Relevant:
Query: Bariatric surgery has a positive impact on mental health. Document: Neither depression nor binge eating disorder was consistently associated with differences in weight outcomes. Relevant:
Query: Bariatric surgery has a positive impact on mental health. Document: Bariatric surgery was, however, consistently associated with postoperative decreases in the prevalence of depression (7 studies; 8%-74% decrease) and the severity of depressive symptoms (6 studies; 40%-70% decrease). Relevant:
Query: Bariatric surgery has a positive impact on mental health. Document: CONCLUSIONS AND RELEVANCE Mental health conditions are common among bariatric surgery patients-in particular, depression and binge eating disorder. Relevant:
Query: Bariatric surgery has a positive impact on mental health. Document: There is inconsistent evidence regarding the association between preoperative mental health conditions and postoperative weight loss. Relevant:
Query: Bariatric surgery has a positive impact on mental health. Document: Moderate-quality evidence supports an association between bariatric surgery and lower rates of depression postoperatively. Relevant:
Query: Bariatric surgery has a positive impact on mental health. Document: Extreme obesity is associated with severe psychiatric and somatic comorbidity and impairment of psychosocial functioning. Relevant:
Query: Bariatric surgery has a positive impact on mental health. Document: Bariatric surgery is the most effective treatment not only with regard to weight loss but also with obesity-associated illnesses. Relevant:
Query: Bariatric surgery has a positive impact on mental health. Document: Health-related psychological and psychosocial variables have been increasingly considered as important outcome variables of bariatric surgery. Relevant:
Query: Bariatric surgery has a positive impact on mental health. Document: However, the long-term impact of bariatric surgery on psychological and psychosocial functioning is largely unclear. Relevant:
Query: Bariatric surgery has a positive impact on mental health. Document: The aim of this study was to evaluate the relationship between the course of weight and psychological variables including depression, anxiety, health-related quality of life (HRQOL), and self-esteem up to 4 years after obesity surgery. Relevant:
Query: Bariatric surgery has a positive impact on mental health. Document: By standardized questionnaires prior to (T1) and 1 year (T2), 2 years (T3), and 4 years (T4) after surgery, 148 patients (47 males (31.8 %), 101 females (68.2 %), mean age 38.8 ± 10.2 years) were assessed. Relevant:
Query: Bariatric surgery has a positive impact on mental health. Document: On average, participants lost 24.6 % of their initial weight 1 year after surgery, 25.1 % after 2 years, and 22.3 % after 4 years. Relevant:
Query: Bariatric surgery has a positive impact on mental health. Document: Statistical analysis revealed significant improvements in depressive symptoms, physical dimension of quality of life, and self-esteem with peak improvements 1 year after surgery. Relevant:
Query: Bariatric surgery has a positive impact on mental health. Document: These improvements were largely maintained. Relevant:
Query: Bariatric surgery has a positive impact on mental health. Document: Significant correlations between weight loss and improvements in depression, physical aspects of HRQOL (T2, T3, and T4), and self-esteem (T3) were observed. Relevant:
Query: Bariatric surgery has a positive impact on mental health. Document: Corresponding to the considerable weight loss after bariatric surgery, important aspects of mental health improved significantly during the 4-year follow-up period. Relevant:
Query: Bariatric surgery has a positive impact on mental health. Document: However, parallel to weight regain, psychological improvements showed a slow but not significant decline over time. Relevant:
Query: Bariatric surgery has a positive impact on mental health. Document: Pre-operative psychological assessment is recommended by international guidelines for bariatric surgery candidates. Relevant:
Query: Bariatric surgery has a positive impact on mental health. Document: Thereby, service teams caring for bariatric patients should include at least one mental health provider (e.g., a psychologist or psychiatrist). Relevant:
Query: Bariatric surgery has a positive impact on mental health. Document: The objective of this study was to evaluate the psychology and psychiatry resources and practices in the 37 specialized obesity centers (CSOs) created by the French Ministry of Health. Relevant:
Query: Bariatric surgery has a positive impact on mental health. Document: CSO coordinators were contacted by e-mail to collect general information on the centers (e.g., number of bariatric operations). Relevant:
Query: Bariatric surgery has a positive impact on mental health. Document: Secondly, psychologists and psychiatrists of each center completed an anonymous questionnaire assessing their professional practices and their organization of care pathways. Relevant:
Query: Bariatric surgery has a positive impact on mental health. Document: The vast majority of CSO coordinators (81%, n = 26/32) answered our survey. Relevant:
Query: Bariatric surgery has a positive impact on mental health. Document: These results show significant differences and shortages in terms of the psychology/psychiatry resources available. Relevant:
Query: Bariatric surgery has a positive impact on mental health. Document: Most of the psychologists (n = 26/31) and psychiatrists (n = 10/10) stated that they systematically meet new patients only before surgery (56%) or both before and after the operation (30%); however, some psychologists and psychiatrists (14%) do not systematically meet all the patients (before and/or after surgery). Relevant:
Query: Bariatric surgery has a positive impact on mental health. Document: Nevertheless, all the professionals provide psychology assessments, and about 75% of them offer a psychological follow-up, indicating a similarity regarding the practices of psychologists and psychiatrists. Relevant:
Query: Bariatric surgery has a positive impact on mental health. Document: Our results highlight the place of psychological/psychiatric evaluations in French CSOs and emphasize the absence of mental health providers in several of these services. Relevant:
Query: Bariatric surgery has a positive impact on mental health. Document: Post-operative psychological follow-up is not usually provided. Relevant:
Query: Bariatric surgery has a positive impact on mental health. Document: It would be appropriate to create clear recommendations for post-operative psychological or psychiatric long-term follow-up. Relevant:
Query: Basophils counteract disease development in patients with systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE). Document: In systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE), self-reactive antibodies can target the kidney (lupus nephritis), leading to functional failure and possible mortality. Relevant:
Query: Basophils counteract disease development in patients with systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE). Document: We report that activation of basophils by autoreactive IgE causes their homing to lymph nodes, promoting T helper type 2 (T(H)2) cell differentiation and enhancing the production of self-reactive antibodies that cause lupus-like nephritis in mice lacking the Src family protein tyrosine kinase Lyn (Lyn(-/-) mice). Relevant:
Query: Basophils counteract disease development in patients with systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE). Document: Individuals with SLE also have elevated serum IgE, self-reactive IgEs and activated basophils that express CD62 ligand (CD62L) and the major histocompatibility complex (MHC) class II molecule human leukocyte antigen-DR (HLA-DR), parameters that are associated with increased disease activity and active lupus nephritis. Relevant:
Query: Basophils counteract disease development in patients with systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE). Document: Basophils were also present in the lymph nodes and spleen of subjects with SLE. Relevant:
Query: Basophils counteract disease development in patients with systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE). Document: Thus, in Lyn(-/-) mice, basophils and IgE autoantibodies amplify autoantibody production that leads to lupus nephritis, and in individuals with SLE IgE autoantibodies and activated basophils are factors associated with disease activity and nephritis. Relevant:
Query: Basophils counteract disease development in patients with systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE). Document: Systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE) is a systemic autoimmune disease characterized by a breakdown of tolerance to nuclear antigens and the development of immune complexes. Relevant:
Query: Basophils counteract disease development in patients with systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE). Document: Genomic approaches have shown that human SLE leukocytes homogeneously express type I interferon (IFN)-induced and neutrophil-related transcripts. Relevant:
Query: Basophils counteract disease development in patients with systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE). Document: Increased production and/or bioavailability of IFN-α and associated alterations in dendritic cell (DC) homeostasis have been linked to lupus pathogenesis. Relevant:
Query: Basophils counteract disease development in patients with systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE). Document: Although neutrophils have long been shown to be associated with lupus, their potential role in disease pathogenesis remains elusive. Relevant:
Query: Basophils counteract disease development in patients with systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE). Document: Here, we show that mature SLE neutrophils are primed in vivo by type I IFN and die upon exposure to SLE-derived anti-ribonucleoprotein antibodies, releasing neutrophil extracellular traps (NETs). Query: Birth-weight is positively associated with breast cancer. Document: Birth weight was positively associated with breast cancer risk in studies based on birth records (pooled relative risk [RR] per one standard deviation [SD] [= 0.5 kg] increment in birth weight: 1.06; 95% confidence interval [CI] 1.02-1.09) and parental recall when the participants were children (1.02; 95% CI 0.99-1.05), but not in those based on adult self-reports, or maternal recall during the woman's adulthood (0.98; 95% CI 0.95-1.01) (p for heterogeneity between data sources = 0.003). Relevant:
Query: Birth-weight is positively associated with breast cancer. Document: Relative to women who weighed 3.000-3.499 kg, the risk was 0.96 (CI 0.80-1.16) in those who weighed < 2.500 kg, and 1.12 (95% CI 1.00-1.25) in those who weighed > or = 4.000 kg (p for linear trend = 0.001) in birth record data. Relevant:

Query: Birth-weight is positively associated with breast cancer. Document: RESULTS Of 314,019 women in the cohort, 2216 (0.7%) developed breast cancer during the follow-up through 2001, of whom 2100 (95%) were diagnosed before age 50 years. Relevant:
Query: Birth-weight is positively associated with breast cancer. Document: Compared with women who had placentas weighing less than 500 g in 2 consecutive pregnancies, the risk of breast cancer was increased among women whose placentas weighed between 500 and 699 g in their first pregnancy and at least 700 g in their second pregnancy (or vice versa) (adjusted hazard ratio, 1.82; 95% confidence interval [CI], 1.07-3.08), and the corresponding risk was doubled among women whose placentas weighed at least 700 g in both pregnancies (adjusted hazard ratio, 2.05; 95% CI, 1.15-3.64). Query: Birth-weight is positively associated with breast cancer. Document: RESULTS We found that heavier birth weights were associated with increased breast cancer risk, with studies involving five categories of birth weight identifying odds ratios (ORs) of 1.24 (95% confidence interval [CI] 1.04 to 1.48) for 4,000 g or more and 1.15 (95% CI 1.04 to 1.26) for 3,500 g to 3,999 g, relative to a birth weight of 2,500 to 2,599 g. Query: Birth-weight is positively associated with breast cancer. Query: Chronic aerobic exercise alters endothelial function, improving vasodilating mechanisms mediated by NO. Document: Aerobic exercise training induces an increase in coronary blood flow capacity that is associated with altered control of coronary vascular resistance and, therefore, coronary blood flow. Relevant:
Query: Chronic aerobic exercise alters endothelial function, improving vasodilating mechanisms mediated by NO. Document: The relative importance of metabolic, myogenic, endothelium-mediated, and neurohumoral control systems varies throughout the coronary arterial tree, and these control systems contribute in parallel to regulating coronary vascular resistance to differing degrees at each level in the coronary arterial tree. Relevant:
Query: Chronic aerobic exercise alters endothelial function, improving vasodilating mechanisms mediated by NO. Document: In addition to this nonuniformity of the relative importance of vascular control systems in the coronary arterial tree, it appears that exercise training-induced adaptations are also distributed spatially, in a nonuniform manner throughout the coronary tree. Relevant:
Query: Chronic aerobic exercise alters endothelial function, improving vasodilating mechanisms mediated by NO. Document: As a result, it is necessary to examine training-induced adaptations throughout the coronary arterial tree. Relevant:
Query: Chronic aerobic exercise alters endothelial function, improving vasodilating mechanisms mediated by NO. Document: Adaptations in endothelium-mediated control play a role in training-induced changes in control of coronary vascular resistance, and there is evidence that the effects of training may be different in large coronary arteries than in the microcirculation. Relevant:
Query: Chronic aerobic exercise alters endothelial function, improving vasodilating mechanisms mediated by NO. Document: Also, there is evidence that the mode, frequency, and intensity of exercise training bouts and duration of training may influence the adaptive changes in endothelial function. Relevant:
Query: Chronic aerobic exercise alters endothelial function, improving vasodilating mechanisms mediated by NO. Document: Exercise training has also been shown to induce changes in responses of coronary vascular smooth muscle to vasoactive agents and alterations in the cellular-molecular control of intracellular Ca2+ in coronary vascular smooth muscle of conduit coronary arteries and to enhance myogenic reactivity of coronary resistance arteries. Relevant:
Query: Chronic aerobic exercise alters endothelial function, improving vasodilating mechanisms mediated by NO. Document: Exercise training also appears to have different effects on vascular smooth muscle in large coronary arteries than in the microcirculation. Relevant:
Query: Chronic aerobic exercise alters endothelial function, improving vasodilating mechanisms mediated by NO. Document: For example, adenosine sensitivity is increased in conduit coronary arteries and large resistance arteries after training but is not altered in small coronary resistance arteries of trained animals. Relevant:

Document: Although much remains to be studied, evidence clearly indicates that chronic exercise alters the phenotype of coronary endothelial and vascular smooth muscle cells and that plasticity of these cells plays a role in adaptation of the cardiovascular system in exercise training. Query: Cold exposure increases BAT recruitment. Document: Uncoupling protein 1 (Ucp1), which is localized in the mitochondrial inner membrane of mammalian brown adipose tissue (BAT), generates heat by uncoupling oxidative phosphorylation. Relevant:
Query: Cold exposure increases BAT recruitment. Document: Upon cold exposure or nutritional abundance, sympathetic neurons stimulate BAT to express Ucp1 to induce energy dissipation and thermogenesis. Relevant:
Query: Cold exposure increases BAT recruitment. Document: Accordingly, increased Ucp1 expression reduces obesity in mice and is correlated with leanness in humans. Relevant:
Query: Cold exposure increases BAT recruitment. Document: Despite this significance, there is currently a limited understanding of how Ucp1 expression is physiologically regulated at the molecular level. Relevant:
Query: Cold exposure increases BAT recruitment. Document: Here, we describe the involvement of Sestrin2 and reactive oxygen species (ROS) in regulation of Ucp1 expression. Relevant:
Query: Cold exposure increases BAT recruitment. Document: Transgenic overexpression of Sestrin2 in adipose tissues inhibited both basal and cold-induced Ucp1 expression in interscapular BAT, culminating in decreased thermogenesis and increased fat accumulation. Relevant:
Query: Cold exposure increases BAT recruitment. Document: Endogenous Sestrin2 is also important for suppressing Ucp1 expression because BAT from Sestrin2(-/-) mice exhibited a highly elevated level of Ucp1 expression. Relevant:
Query: Cold exposure increases BAT recruitment. Document: The redox-inactive mutant of Sestrin2 was incapable of regulating Ucp1 expression, suggesting that Sestrin2 inhibits Ucp1 expression primarily through reducing ROS accumulation. Relevant:
Query: Cold exposure increases BAT recruitment. Document: Consistently, ROS-suppressing antioxidant chemicals, such as butylated hydroxyanisole and N-acetylcysteine, inhibited cold- or cAMP-induced Ucp1 expression as well. Relevant:
Query: Cold exposure increases BAT recruitment. Document: p38 MAPK, a signaling mediator required for cAMP-induced Ucp1 expression, was inhibited by either Sestrin2 overexpression or antioxidant treatments. Relevant:
Query: Cold exposure increases BAT recruitment. Document: Taken together, these results suggest that Sestrin2 and antioxidants inhibit Ucp1 expression through suppressing ROS-mediated p38 MAPK activation, implying a critical role of ROS in proper BAT metabolism. Relevant:
Query: Cold exposure increases BAT recruitment. Document: Molecular mechanisms underlying the cold-associated high cardiovascular risk remain unknown. Relevant:
Query: Cold exposure increases BAT recruitment. Document: Here, we show that the cold-triggered food-intake-independent lipolysis significantly increased plasma levels of small low-density lipoprotein (LDL) remnants, leading to accelerated development of atherosclerotic lesions in mice. Relevant:
Query: Cold exposure increases BAT recruitment. Document: In two genetic mouse knockout models (apolipoprotein E(-/-) [ApoE(-/-)] and LDL receptor(-/-) [Ldlr(-/-)] mice), persistent cold exposure stimulated atherosclerotic plaque growth by increasing lipid deposition. Relevant:
Query: Cold exposure increases BAT recruitment. Document: Furthermore, marked increase of inflammatory cells and plaque-associated microvessels were detected in the cold-acclimated ApoE(-/-) and Ldlr(-/-) mice, leading to plaque instability. Relevant:
Query: Cold exposure increases BAT recruitment. Document: Deletion of uncoupling protein 1 (UCP1), a key mitochondrial protein involved in thermogenesis in brown adipose tissue (BAT), in the ApoE(-/-) strain completely protected mice from the cold-induced atherosclerotic lesions. Relevant:
Query: Cold exposure increases BAT recruitment. Document: Cold acclimation markedly reduced plasma levels of adiponectin, and systemic delivery of adiponectin protected ApoE(-/-) mice from plaque development. Relevant:
Query: Cold exposure increases BAT recruitment. Document: These findings provide mechanistic insights on low-temperature-associated cardiovascular risks. Relevant:

Document: For example, neuregulin 4 was more highly expressed in brown adipose tissue and upregulated in white fat upon cold exposure, and cell studies showed that it is a neurite outgrowth-promoting adipokine, indicative of a role in increasing adipose tissue innervation in response to cold. Query: Combination nicotine replacement therapies with varenicline or bupropion lead to significantly higher long-term abstinence rates at 52 weeks than varenicline monotherapy. Document: IMPORTANCE Combining pharmacotherapies for tobacco-dependence treatment may increase smoking abstinence. Relevant:
Query: Combination nicotine replacement therapies with varenicline or bupropion lead to significantly higher long-term abstinence rates at 52 weeks than varenicline monotherapy. Document: OBJECTIVE To determine efficacy and safety of varenicline and bupropion sustained-release (SR; combination therapy) compared with varenicline (monotherapy) in cigarette smokers. Relevant:
Query: Combination nicotine replacement therapies with varenicline or bupropion lead to significantly higher long-term abstinence rates at 52 weeks than varenicline monotherapy. Document: DESIGN, SETTING, AND PARTICIPANTS Randomized, blinded, placebo-controlled multicenter clinical trial with a 12-week treatment period and follow-up through week 52 conducted between October 2009 and April 2013 at 3 midwestern clinical research sites. Relevant:
Query: Combination nicotine replacement therapies with varenicline or bupropion lead to significantly higher long-term abstinence rates at 52 weeks than varenicline monotherapy. Relevant:
Query: Combination nicotine replacement therapies with varenicline or bupropion lead to significantly higher long-term abstinence rates at 52 weeks than varenicline monotherapy. Document: Secondary outcomes were prolonged and point-prevalence smoking abstinence rates at weeks 26 and 52. Relevant:

Query: Combination nicotine replacement therapies with varenicline or bupropion lead to significantly higher long-term abstinence rates at 52 weeks than varenicline monotherapy. Document: RESULTS At 12 weeks, 53.0% of the combination therapy group achieved prolonged smoking abstinence and 56.2% achieved 7-day point-prevalence smoking abstinence compared with 43.2% and 48.6% in varenicline monotherapy (odds ratio [OR], 1.49; 95% CI, 1.05-2.12; P = .03 and OR, 1.36; 95% CI, 0.95-1.93; P = .09, respectively). Relevant:

Document: At 26 weeks, 36.6% of the combination therapy group achieved prolonged and 38.2% achieved 7-day point-prevalence smoking abstinence compared with 27.6% and 31.9% in varenicline monotherapy (OR, 1.52; 95% CI, 1.04-2.22; P = .03 and OR, 1.32; 95% CI, 0.91-1.91; P = .14, respectively). Query: Dexamethasone decreases risk of postoperative bleeding. Document: OBJECTIVE To assess whether dexamethasone dose-dependently reduces the risk of PONV at 24 hours after tonsillectomy. Relevant:
Query: Dexamethasone decreases risk of postoperative bleeding. Document: DESIGN, SETTING, AND PATIENTS Randomized placebo-controlled trial conducted among 215 children undergoing elective tonsillectomy at a major public teaching hospital in Switzerland from February 2005 to December 2007. Relevant:
Query: Dexamethasone decreases risk of postoperative bleeding. Document: INTERVENTIONS Children were randomly assigned to receive dexamethasone (0.05, 0.15, or 0.5 mg/kg) or placebo intravenously after induction of anesthesia. Relevant:
Query: Dexamethasone decreases risk of postoperative bleeding. Document: Acetaminophen-codeine and ibuprofen were given as postoperative analgesia. Relevant:
Query: Dexamethasone decreases risk of postoperative bleeding. Document: Follow-up continued until the 10th postoperative day. Relevant:
Query: Dexamethasone decreases risk of postoperative bleeding. Document: MAIN OUTCOME MEASURES The primary end point was prevention of PONV at 24 hours; secondary end points were decrease in the need for ibuprofen at 24 hours and evaluation of adverse effects. Relevant:
Query: Dexamethasone decreases risk of postoperative bleeding. Document: RESULTS At 24 hours, 24 of 54 participants who received placebo (44%; 95% confidence interval [CI], 31%-59%) had experienced PONV compared with 20 of 53 (38%; 95% CI, 25%-52%), 13 of 54 (24%; 95% CI, 13%-38%), and 6 of 52 (12%; 95% CI, 4%-23%) who received dexamethasone at 0.05, 0.15, and 0.5 mg/kg, respectively (P<.001 for linear trend). Query: Dexamethasone decreases risk of postoperative bleeding. Document: children who received placebo had bleeding compared with 6 of 53 (11%; 95% CI, 4%-23%), 2 of 51 (4%; 95% CI, 0.5%-13%), and 12 of 50 (24%; 95% CI, 13%-38%) who received dexamethasone at 0.05, 0.15, and 0.5 mg/kg, respectively (P = .003). Query: Epidemiological disease burden from noncommunicable diseases is more prevalent in low economic settings. Document: Data on epidemiology were reported in 31, HRQoL burden in 16, and economic burden in 7 studies. Relevant:

Query: Epidemiological disease burden from noncommunicable diseases is more prevalent in low economic settings. Document: BED was associated with significant impairment in aspects of HRQoL relating to both physical and mental health; the Short Form 36 Physical and Mental Component Summary mean scores varied between 31.1 to 47.3 and 32.0 to 49.8, respectively. Query: Epigenetic modulating agents (EMAs) modulate antitumor immune response in a cancer model system. Document: Epithelial ovarian cancer (EOC) is characterized by an immune suppressive microenvironment, and response of ovarian cancers to immune therapies has thus far been disappointing. Relevant:
Query: Epigenetic modulating agents (EMAs) modulate antitumor immune response in a cancer model system. Document: We now find, in a mouse model of EOC, that clinically relevant doses of DNA methyltransferase and histone deacetylase inhibitors (DNMTi and HDACi, respectively) reduce the immune suppressive microenvironment through type I IFN signaling and improve response to immune checkpoint therapy. Relevant:
Query: Epigenetic modulating agents (EMAs) modulate antitumor immune response in a cancer model system. Document: These data indicate that the type I IFN response is required for effective in vivo antitumorigenic actions of the DNMTi 5-azacytidine (AZA). Relevant:

Document: Through type I IFN signaling, AZA increases the numbers of CD45+ immune cells and the percentage of active CD8+ T and natural killer (NK) cells in the tumor microenvironment, while reducing tumor burden and extending survival. Relevant:
Query: Epigenetic modulating agents (EMAs) modulate antitumor immune response in a cancer model system. Document: AZA also increases viral defense gene expression in both tumor and immune cells, and reduces the percentage of macrophages and myeloid-derived suppressor cells in the tumor microenvironment. Relevant:
Query: Epigenetic modulating agents (EMAs) modulate antitumor immune response in a cancer model system. Document: The addition of an HDACi to AZA enhances the modulation of the immune microenvironment, specifically increasing T and NK cell activation and reducing macrophages over AZA treatment alone, while further increasing the survival of the mice. Relevant:
Query: Epigenetic modulating agents (EMAs) modulate antitumor immune response in a cancer model system. Document: Finally, a triple combination of DNMTi/HDACi plus the immune checkpoint inhibitor α-PD-1 provides the best antitumor effect and longest overall survival, and may be an attractive candidate for future clinical trials in ovarian cancer. Query: Errors in peripheral IV drug administration are most common during bolus administration and multiple-step medicine preparations. Document: OBJECTIVES To determine the incidence and clinical importance of errors in the preparation and administration of intravenous drugs and the stages of the process in which errors occur. Relevant:
Query: Errors in peripheral IV drug administration are most common during bolus administration and multiple-step medicine preparations. Document: DESIGN Prospective ethnographic study using disguised observation. Relevant:
Query: Errors in peripheral IV drug administration are most common during bolus administration and multiple-step medicine preparations. Document: PARTICIPANTS Nurses who prepared and administered intravenous drugs. Relevant:
Query: Errors in peripheral IV drug administration are most common during bolus administration and multiple-step medicine preparations. Document: SETTING 10 wards in a teaching and non-teaching hospital in the United Kingdom. Relevant:
Query: Errors in peripheral IV drug administration are most common during bolus administration and multiple-step medicine preparations. Document: MAIN OUTCOME MEASURES Number, type, and clinical importance of errors. Relevant:
Query: Errors in peripheral IV drug administration are most common during bolus administration and multiple-step medicine preparations. Document: RESULTS 249 errors were identified. Relevant:
Query: Errors in peripheral IV drug administration are most common during bolus administration and multiple-step medicine preparations. Document: At least one error occurred in 212 out of 430 intravenous drug doses (49%, 95% confidence interval 45% to 54%). Relevant:
Query: Errors in peripheral IV drug administration are most common during bolus administration and multiple-step medicine preparations. Document: Three doses (1%) had potentially severe errors, 126 (29%) potentially moderate errors, and 83 (19%) potentially minor errors. Relevant:
Query: Errors in peripheral IV drug administration are most common during bolus administration and multiple-step medicine preparations. Document: Most errors occurred when giving bolus doses or making up drugs that required multiple step preparation. Relevant:
Query: Errors in peripheral IV drug administration are most common during bolus administration and multiple-step medicine preparations. Document: CONCLUSIONS The rate of intravenous drug errors was high. Relevant:
Query: Errors in peripheral IV drug administration are most common during bolus administration and multiple-step medicine preparations. Document: Although most errors would cause only short term adverse effects, a few could have been serious. Relevant:
Query: Errors in peripheral IV drug administration are most common during bolus administration and multiple-step medicine preparations. Document: A combination of reducing the amount of preparation on the ward, training, and technology to administer slow bolus doses would probably have the greatest effect on error rates. Relevant:
Query: Errors in peripheral IV drug administration are most common during bolus administration and multiple-step medicine preparations. Document: OBJECTIVES To assess incidence and preventability of adverse drug events (ADEs) and potential ADEs. Relevant:
Query: Errors in peripheral IV drug administration are most common during bolus administration and multiple-step medicine preparations. Document: To analyze preventable events to develop prevention strategies. Relevant:
Query: Errors in peripheral IV drug administration are most common during bolus administration and multiple-step medicine preparations. Document: DESIGN Prospective cohort study. Relevant:
Query: Errors in peripheral IV drug administration are most common during bolus administration and multiple-step medicine preparations. Document: PARTICIPANTS All 4031 adult admissions to a stratified random sample of 11 medical and surgical units in two tertiary care hospitals over a 6-month period. Relevant:
Query: Errors in peripheral IV drug administration are most common during bolus administration and multiple-step medicine preparations. Document: Units included two medical and three surgical intensive care units and four medical and two surgical general care units. Relevant:
Query: Errors in peripheral IV drug administration are most common during bolus administration and multiple-step medicine preparations. Document: MAIN OUTCOME MEASURES Adverse drug events and potential ADEs. Relevant:
Query: Errors in peripheral IV drug administration are most common during bolus administration and multiple-step medicine preparations. Document: METHODS Incidents were detected by stimulated self-report by nurses and pharmacists and by daily review of all charts by nurse investigators. Relevant:
Query: Errors in peripheral IV drug administration are most common during bolus administration and multiple-step medicine preparations. Document: Incidents were subsequently classified by two independent reviewers as to whether they represented ADEs or potential ADEs and as to severity and preventability. Relevant:
Query: Errors in peripheral IV drug administration are most common during bolus administration and multiple-step medicine preparations. Document: RESULTS Over 6 months, 247 ADEs and 194 potential ADEs were identified. Relevant:
Query: Errors in peripheral IV drug administration are most common during bolus administration and multiple-step medicine preparations. Document: Extrapolated event rates were 6.5 ADEs and 5.5 potential ADEs per 100 nonobstetrical admissions, for mean numbers per hospital per year of approximately 1900 ADEs and 1600 potential ADEs. Relevant:
Query: Errors in peripheral IV drug administration are most common during bolus administration and multiple-step medicine preparations. Document: Of all ADEs, 1% were fatal (none preventable), 12% life-threatening, 30% serious, and 57% significant. Relevant:
Query: Errors in peripheral IV drug administration are most common during bolus administration and multiple-step medicine preparations. Document: Twenty-eight percent were judged preventable. Relevant:
Query: Errors in peripheral IV drug administration are most common during bolus administration and multiple-step medicine preparations. Document: Of the life-threatening and serious ADEs, 42% were preventable, compared with 18% of significant ADEs. Relevant:
Query: Errors in peripheral IV drug administration are most common during bolus administration and multiple-step medicine preparations. Document: Errors resulting in preventable ADEs occurred most often at the stages of ordering (56%) and administration (34%); transcription (6%) and dispensing errors (4%) were less common. Relevant:
Query: Errors in peripheral IV drug administration are most common during bolus administration and multiple-step medicine preparations. Document: Errors were much more likely to be intercepted if the error occurred earlier in the process: 48% at the ordering stage vs 0% at the administration stage. Relevant:
Query: Errors in peripheral IV drug administration are most common during bolus administration and multiple-step medicine preparations. Document: CONCLUSION Adverse drug events were common and often preventable; serious ADEs were more likely to be preventable. Relevant:
Query: Errors in peripheral IV drug administration are most common during bolus administration and multiple-step medicine preparations. Document: Most resulted from errors at the ordering stage, but many also occurred at the administration stage. Relevant:
Query: Errors in peripheral IV drug administration are most common during bolus administration and multiple-step medicine preparations. Document: Prevention strategies should target both stages of the drug delivery process. Relevant:
Query: Errors in peripheral IV drug administration are most common during bolus administration and multiple-step medicine preparations. Document: The validity and reliability of observational methods for studying medication administration errors (MAEs) were studied. Relevant:
Query: Errors in peripheral IV drug administration are most common during bolus administration and multiple-step medicine preparations. Document: Between January and June 1998, two pharmacists observed consecutive drug administration rounds by nurses on two wards in a U.K. hospital and recorded all MAEs identified. Relevant:
Query: Errors in peripheral IV drug administration are most common during bolus administration and multiple-step medicine preparations. Document: The observers intervened in cases of potentially harmful errors. Relevant:
Query: Errors in peripheral IV drug administration are most common during bolus administration and multiple-step medicine preparations. Document: MAE records were audited to determine the percentage of omitted doses for which a corresponding reason was documented for the observation periods and for nonobservation periods. Relevant:
Query: Errors in peripheral IV drug administration are most common during bolus administration and multiple-step medicine preparations. Document: Error rates for each drug administration round were analyzed according to whether they were for the nurse's first, second, third (and so on) observed round. Relevant:
Query: Errors in peripheral IV drug administration are most common during bolus administration and multiple-step medicine preparations. Document: Error rates were calculated before and after the first intervention with nurses for whom an intervention was made. Relevant:
Query: Errors in peripheral IV drug administration are most common during bolus administration and multiple-step medicine preparations. Document: Observer reliability was calculated by comparing the rates of errors identified by the two observers. Relevant:
Query: Errors in peripheral IV drug administration are most common during bolus administration and multiple-step medicine preparations. Document: There was no difference between the observation and nonobservation periods in the percentage of omitted doses for which a reason was documented, and there was no change in the error rate with repeated observations. Relevant:
Query: Errors in peripheral IV drug administration are most common during bolus administration and multiple-step medicine preparations. Document: There was no difference in error rates before and after the first intervention for each nurse. Relevant:
Query: Errors in peripheral IV drug administration are most common during bolus administration and multiple-step medicine preparations. Document: There was also no difference in error detection between the two observers and no change with increasing duration of observation. Relevant:
Query: Errors in peripheral IV drug administration are most common during bolus administration and multiple-step medicine preparations. Document: Observation of nurses during drug administration at a U.K. hospital did not significantly affect the MAE rate; nor did tactful interventions by the observers. Relevant:
Query: Errors in peripheral IV drug administration are most common during bolus administration and multiple-step medicine preparations. Document: Observer reliability was high. Relevant:
Query: Errors in peripheral IV drug administration are most common during bolus administration and multiple-step medicine preparations. Document: Concerns about the validity and reliability of observational methods for identifying MAEs may be unfounded. Relevant:

Query: Ethanol stress decreases the expression of IBP in bacteria. Document: Despite the high sugar content (∼6% glucose, 3% xylose) and relatively low toxicity of this hydrolysate, E. coli ceased growth long before glucose was depleted. Relevant:
Query: Ethanol stress decreases the expression of IBP in bacteria. Document: Nevertheless, the cells remained metabolically active and continued conversion of glucose to ethanol until all glucose was consumed. Relevant:
Query: Ethanol stress decreases the expression of IBP in bacteria. Document: Gene expression profiling revealed complex and changing patterns of metabolic physiology and cellular stress responses during an exponential growth phase, a transition phase, and the glycolytically active stationary phase. Relevant:
Query: Ethanol stress decreases the expression of IBP in bacteria. Document: During the exponential and transition phases, high cell maintenance and stress response costs were mitigated, in part, by free amino acids available in the hydrolysate. Relevant:
Query: Ethanol stress decreases the expression of IBP in bacteria. Document: However, after the majority of amino acids were depleted, the cells entered stationary phase, and ATP derived from glucose fermentation was consumed entirely by the demands of cell maintenance in the hydrolysate. Relevant:
Query: Ethanol stress decreases the expression of IBP in bacteria. Document: Comparative gene expression profiling and metabolic modeling of the ethanologen suggested that the high energetic cost of mitigating osmotic, lignotoxin, and ethanol stress collectively limits growth, sugar utilization rates, and ethanol yields in alkali-pretreated lignocellulosic hydrolysates. Query: Exposure to fine particulate air pollution is relate to anxiety prevalence. Document: OBJECTIVE To determine whether higher past exposure to particulate air pollution is associated with prevalent high symptoms of anxiety. Relevant:
Query: Exposure to fine particulate air pollution is relate to anxiety prevalence. Document: DESIGN Observational cohort study. Relevant:
Query: Exposure to fine particulate air pollution is relate to anxiety prevalence. Document: SETTING Nurses' Health Study. Relevant:
Query: Exposure to fine particulate air pollution is relate to anxiety prevalence. Document: PARTICIPANTS 71,271 women enrolled in the Nurses' Health Study residing throughout the contiguous United States who had valid estimates on exposure to particulate matter for at least one exposure period of interest and data on anxiety symptoms. Relevant:
Query: Exposure to fine particulate air pollution is relate to anxiety prevalence. Document: MAIN OUTCOME MEASURES Meaningfully high symptoms of anxiety, defined as a score of 6 points or greater on the phobic anxiety subscale of the Crown-Crisp index, administered in 2004. Relevant:
Query: Exposure to fine particulate air pollution is relate to anxiety prevalence. Document: RESULTS The 71,271 eligible women were aged between 57 and 85 years (mean 70 years) at the time of assessment of anxiety symptoms, with a prevalence of high anxiety symptoms of 15%. Relevant:
Query: Exposure to fine particulate air pollution is relate to anxiety prevalence. Document: Exposure to particulate matter was characterized using estimated average exposure to particulate matter <2.5 μm in diameter (PM2.5) and 2.5 to 10 μm in diameter (PM2.5-10) in the one month, three months, six months, one year, and 15 years prior to assessment of anxiety symptoms, and residential distance to the nearest major road two years prior to assessment. Relevant:
Query: Exposure to fine particulate air pollution is relate to anxiety prevalence. Document: Significantly increased odds of high anxiety symptoms were observed with higher exposure to PM2.5 for multiple averaging periods (for example, odds ratio per 10 µg/m(3) increase in prior one month average PM2.5: 1.12, 95% confidence interval 1.06 to 1.19; in prior 12 month average PM2.5: 1.15, 1.06 to 1.26). Relevant:
Query: Exposure to fine particulate air pollution is relate to anxiety prevalence. Document: Models including multiple exposure windows suggested short term averaging periods were more relevant than long term averaging periods. Relevant:
Query: Exposure to fine particulate air pollution is relate to anxiety prevalence. Document: There was no association between anxiety and exposure to PM2.5-10. Relevant:
Query: Exposure to fine particulate air pollution is relate to anxiety prevalence. Document: Residential proximity to major roads was not related to anxiety symptoms in a dose dependent manner. Relevant:
Query: Exposure to fine particulate air pollution is relate to anxiety prevalence. Document: CONCLUSIONS Exposure to fine particulate matter (PM2.5) was associated with high symptoms of anxiety, with more recent exposures potentially more relevant than more distant exposures. Relevant:
Query: Exposure to fine particulate air pollution is relate to anxiety prevalence. Document: Research evaluating whether reductions in exposure to ambient PM2.5 would reduce the population level burden of clinically relevant symptoms of anxiety is warranted. Relevant:
Query: Exposure to fine particulate air pollution is relate to anxiety prevalence. Document: RATIONALE Exposure to particulate air pollution has been related to increased hospitalization and death, particularly from cardiovascular disease. Relevant:
Query: Exposure to fine particulate air pollution is relate to anxiety prevalence. Document: Lower blood DNA methylation content is found in processes related to cardiovascular outcomes, such as oxidative stress, aging, and atherosclerosis. Relevant:

Query: Exposure to fine particulate air pollution is relate to anxiety prevalence. Document: METHODS We measured DNA methylation of long interspersed nucleotide element (LINE)-1 and Alu repetitive elements by quantitative polymerase chain reaction-pyrosequencing of 1,097 blood samples from 718 elderly participants in the Boston area Normative Aging Study. Document: We estimated the effects on DNA methylation of ambient particulate pollutants (black carbon, particulate matter with aerodynamic diameter < or = 2.5 microm [PM2.5], or sulfate) in multiple time windows (4 h to 7 d) before the examination. Relevant:
Query: Exposure to fine particulate air pollution is relate to anxiety prevalence. Document: We estimated standardized regression coefficients (beta) expressing the fraction of a standard deviation change in DNA methylation associated with a standard deviation increase in exposure. Relevant:
Query: Exposure to fine particulate air pollution is relate to anxiety prevalence. Document: MEASUREMENTS AND MAIN RESULTS Repetitive element DNA methylation varied in association with time-related variables, such as day of the week and season. Relevant:
Query: Exposure to fine particulate air pollution is relate to anxiety prevalence. Document: LINE-1 methylation decreased after recent exposure to higher black carbon (beta = -0.11; 95% confidence interval [CI], -0.18 to -0.04; P = 0.002) and PM2.5 (beta = -0.13; 95% CI, -0.19 to -0.06; P < 0.001 for the 7-d moving average). Relevant:
Query: Exposure to fine particulate air pollution is relate to anxiety prevalence. Document: In two-pollutant models, only black carbon, a tracer of traffic particles, was significantly associated with LINE-1 methylation (beta = -0.09; 95% CI, -0.17 to -0.01; P = 0.03). Relevant:
Query: Exposure to fine particulate air pollution is relate to anxiety prevalence. Document: No association was found with Alu methylation (P > 0.12). Relevant:
Query: Exposure to fine particulate air pollution is relate to anxiety prevalence. Document: CONCLUSIONS We found decreased repeated-element methylation after exposure to traffic particles. Relevant:
Query: Exposure to fine particulate air pollution is relate to anxiety prevalence. Document: Whether decreased methylation mediates exposure-related health effects remains to be determined. Relevant:

Query: Febrile seizures increase the threshold for development of epilepsy. Document: Febrile (fever-induced) seizures affect 3–5% of infants and young children. Relevant:
Query: Febrile seizures increase the threshold for development of epilepsy. Document: Despite the high incidence of febrile seizures, their contribution to the development of epilepsy later in life has remained controversial. Relevant:
Query: Febrile seizures increase the threshold for development of epilepsy. Document: Combining a new rat model of complex febrile seizures and patch clamp techniques, we determined that hyperthermia-induced seizures in the immature rat cause a selective presynaptic increase in inhibitory synaptic transmission in the hippocampus that lasts into adulthood. Relevant:
Query: Febrile seizures increase the threshold for development of epilepsy. Document: The long-lasting nature of these potent alterations in synaptic communication after febrile seizures does not support the prevalent view of the 'benign' nature of early-life febrile convulsions. Relevant:
Query: Febrile seizures increase the threshold for development of epilepsy. Document: Understanding molecular mechanisms mediating epileptogenesis is critical for developing more effective therapies for epilepsy. Relevant:
Query: Febrile seizures increase the threshold for development of epilepsy. Document: We recently found that the mammalian target of rapamycin (mTOR) signaling pathway is involved in epileptogenesis, and mTOR inhibitors prevent epilepsy in a mouse model of tuberous sclerosis complex. Relevant:
Query: Febrile seizures increase the threshold for development of epilepsy. Document: Here, we investigated the potential role of mTOR in a rat model of temporal lobe epilepsy initiated by status epilepticus. Relevant:
Query: Febrile seizures increase the threshold for development of epilepsy. Document: Acute kainate-induced seizures resulted in biphasic activation of the mTOR pathway, as evident by an increase in phospho-S6 (P-S6) expression. Relevant:
Query: Febrile seizures increase the threshold for development of epilepsy. Document: An initial rise in P-S6 expression started approximately 1 h after seizure onset, peaked at 3-6 h, and returned to baseline by 24 h in both hippocampus and neocortex, reflecting widespread stimulation of mTOR signaling by acute seizure activity. Relevant:
Query: Febrile seizures increase the threshold for development of epilepsy. Document: After resolution of status epilepticus, a second increase in P-S6 was observed in hippocampus only, which started at 3 d, peaked 5-10 d, and persisted for several weeks after kainate injection, correlating with the development of chronic epileptogenesis within hippocampus. Relevant:
Query: Febrile seizures increase the threshold for development of epilepsy. Document: The mTOR inhibitor rapamycin, administered before kainate, blocked both the acute and chronic phases of seizure-induced mTOR activation and decreased kainate-induced neuronal cell death, neurogenesis, mossy fiber sprouting, and the development of spontaneous epilepsy. Relevant:
Query: Febrile seizures increase the threshold for development of epilepsy. Document: Late rapamycin treatment, after termination of status epilepticus, blocked the chronic phase of mTOR activation and reduced mossy fiber sprouting and epilepsy but not neurogenesis or neuronal death. Relevant:
Query: Febrile seizures increase the threshold for development of epilepsy. Document: These findings indicate that mTOR signaling mediates mechanisms of epileptogenesis in the kainate rat model and that mTOR inhibitors have potential antiepileptogenic effects in this model. Relevant:
Query: Febrile seizures increase the threshold for development of epilepsy. Document: Brain glial cells, five times more prevalent than neurons, have recently received attention for their potential involvement in epileptic seizures. Relevant:
Query: Febrile seizures increase the threshold for development of epilepsy. Document: Microglia and astrocytes, associated with inflammatory innate immune responses, are responsible for surveillance of brain damage that frequently results in seizures. Relevant:
Query: Febrile seizures increase the threshold for development of epilepsy. Document: Thus, an intriguing suggestion has been put forward that seizures may be facilitated and perhaps triggered by brain immune responses. Relevant:
Query: Febrile seizures increase the threshold for development of epilepsy. Document: Indeed, recent evidence strongly implicates innate immune responses in lowering seizure threshold in experimental models of epilepsy, yet, there is no proof that they can play an independent role in initiating seizures in vivo. Relevant:

Document: Six recent large-scale clinical studies reported a remarkably consistent reduction in the incidence of type 2 diabetes in hypertensive patients treated with either ACE inhibitors or ARAs for 3–6 years, compared with a thiazide diuretic, β-adrenoceptor antagonist, the calcium channel antagonist amlodipine or even placebo. Query: Hypertension is frequently observed in type 1 diabetes patients. Document: The relative risk reduction averaged 14% (p = 0.034) in the CAPPP (Captopril Prevention Project) with captopril compared with a thiazide or β1-adrenoceptor antagonist, 34% (p < 0.001) in the HOPE (Heart Outcomes Prevention Evaluation) study with ramipril compared with placebo, 30% (p < 0.001) in the ALLHAT (Antihypertensive and Lipid-Lowering Treatment to Prevent Heart Attack Trial) with lisinopril compared with chlortalidone, 25% (p < 0.001) in the LIFE (Losartan Intervention For Endpoint reduction in hypertension study) with losartan compared with atenolol, and 25% (p = 0.09) in the SCOPE (Study on Cognition and Prognosis in the Elderly) with candesartan cilexetil compared with placebo, and 23% (p < 0.0001) in the VALUE (Valsartan Antihypertensive Long-term Use Evaluation) trial with valsartan compared with amlodipine. Query: Incidence rates of cervical cancer have decreased. Document: OBJECTIVE To describe the efficacy of the Finnish mass screening program for cervical squamous carcinoma and adenocarcinoma, as reflected by changes of incidence and mortality rate. Relevant:
Query: Incidence rates of cervical cancer have decreased. Document: METHODS Cervical cancer incidence and mortality data were obtained from the Finnish Cancer Registry. Relevant:
Query: Incidence rates of cervical cancer have decreased. Document: Data were available from the year 1953, when the registry was established. Relevant:
Query: Incidence rates of cervical cancer have decreased. Document: The nationwide mass screening program in Finland was started in the mid-1960s. Relevant:
Query: Incidence rates of cervical cancer have decreased. Document: A centralized organization administers this program. Relevant:
Query: Incidence rates of cervical cancer have decreased. Document: Women age 30-60 years are notified for screening every 5 years. Relevant:
Query: Incidence rates of cervical cancer have decreased. Document: RESULTS The mean incidence of cervical carcinoma in the early 1960s was 15.4 per 10(5) woman-years. Relevant:
Query: Incidence rates of cervical cancer have decreased. Document: In 1991, it was only 2.7 per 10(5) woman-years. Relevant:
Query: Incidence rates of cervical cancer have decreased. Document: The mortality rate has decreased in the same proportion since the mass screening program. Relevant:
Query: Incidence rates of cervical cancer have decreased. Document: In the early 1960s, the mortality was 6.6 and in 1991 1.4 per 10(5) woman-years. Relevant:
Query: Incidence rates of cervical cancer have decreased. Document: However, the decrease of the incidence is seen almost exclusively in squamous cell carcinomas. Relevant:
Query: Incidence rates of cervical cancer have decreased. Document: The mortality caused by adenocarcinoma has decreased in screened birth cohorts, but the incidence rate has remained the same. Relevant:
Query: Incidence rates of cervical cancer have decreased. Document: CONCLUSIONS The Finnish mass screening program has been effective and its continuation is of utmost importance. Relevant:
Query: Incidence rates of cervical cancer have decreased. Document: In the future more attention should be given to glandular cell atypias in cervical smears. Relevant:
Query: Incidence rates of cervical cancer have decreased. Document: Thus, it might be possible to decrease the incidence of cervical adenocarcinoma. Relevant:
Query: Incidence rates of cervical cancer have decreased. Document: With respect to cervical cancer management, Finland and the Netherlands are comparable in relevant characteristics, e.g., fertility rate, age-of-mother at first birth and a national screening programme for several years. Relevant:
Query: Incidence rates of cervical cancer have decreased. Document: The aim of this study is to compare trends in incidence of and mortality from cervical cancer in Finland and the Netherlands in relation to the introduction and intensity of the screening programmes. Relevant:
Query: Incidence rates of cervical cancer have decreased. Document: Therefore, incidence and mortality rates were calculated using the Cancer Registries of Finland and the Netherlands. Relevant:
Query: Incidence rates of cervical cancer have decreased. Document: Data on screening intensity were obtained from the Finnish Cancer Registry and the Dutch evaluation centre at ErasmusMC-Rotterdam. Relevant:
Query: Incidence rates of cervical cancer have decreased. Document: Women aged 30-60 have been screened every 5 years, in Finland since 1992 and in the Netherlands since 1996. Relevant:
Query: Incidence rates of cervical cancer have decreased. Document: Screening protocols for smear taking and referral to the gynaecologist are comparable. Relevant:
Query: Incidence rates of cervical cancer have decreased. Document: Incidence and mortality rates have declined more in Finland. Relevant:
Query: Incidence rates of cervical cancer have decreased. Document: In 2003, age-adjusted incidence and mortality in Finland were 4.0 and 0.9 and in the Netherlands 4.9 and 1.4 per 100,000 woman-years, respectively. Relevant:
Query: Incidence rates of cervical cancer have decreased. Document: Excess smear use in the Netherlands was estimated to be 24 per 1,000 women during a 5-year interval compared to 121 in Finland. Relevant:
Query: Incidence rates of cervical cancer have decreased. Document: The decline in mortality in Finland seems to be almost completely related to the screening programme whereas in the Netherlands it was initially considered to be a natural decline. Relevant:
Query: Incidence rates of cervical cancer have decreased. Document: Differences in risk factors might also play a role: the Netherlands has higher population density and higher percentages of immigrants and (female) smokers. Relevant:
Query: Incidence rates of cervical cancer have decreased. Document: The greater excess smear use in Finland might also have affected incidence. Relevant:
Query: Incidence rates of cervical cancer have decreased. Document: BACKGROUND Screening for cervical cancer based on testing for human papillomavirus (HPV) increases the sensitivity of detection of high-grade (grade 2 or 3) cervical intraepithelial neoplasia, but whether this gain represents overdiagnosis or protection against future high-grade cervical epithelial neoplasia or cervical cancer is unknown. Relevant:
Query: Incidence rates of cervical cancer have decreased. Document: METHODS In a population-based screening program in Sweden, 12,527 women 32 to 38 years of age were randomly assigned at a 1:1 ratio to have an HPV test plus a Papanicolaou (Pap) test (intervention group) or a Pap test alone (control group). Relevant:
Query: Incidence rates of cervical cancer have decreased. Document: Women with a positive HPV test and a normal Pap test result were offered a second HPV test at least 1 year later, and those who were found to be persistently infected with the same high-risk type of HPV were then offered colposcopy with cervical biopsy. Relevant:
Query: Incidence rates of cervical cancer have decreased. Document: A similar number of double-blinded Pap smears and colposcopies with biopsy were performed in randomly selected women in the control group. Relevant:
Query: Incidence rates of cervical cancer have decreased. Document: Comprehensive registry data were used to follow the women for a mean of 4.1 years. Relevant:
Query: Incidence rates of cervical cancer have decreased. Document: The relative rates of grade 2 or 3 cervical intraepithelial neoplasia or cancer detected at enrollment and at subsequent screening examinations were calculated. Relevant:
Query: Incidence rates of cervical cancer have decreased. Document: RESULTS At enrollment, the proportion of women in the intervention group who were found to have lesions of grade 2 or 3 cervical intraepithelial neoplasia or cancer was 51% greater (95% confidence interval [CI], 13 to 102) than the proportion of women in the control group who were found to have such lesions. Relevant:
Query: Incidence rates of cervical cancer have decreased. Document: At subsequent screening examinations, the proportion of women in the intervention group who were found to have grade 2 or 3 lesions or cancer was 42% less (95% CI, 4 to 64) and the proportion with grade 3 lesions or cancer was 47% less (95% CI, 2 to 71) than the proportions of control women who were found to have such lesions. Relevant:
Query: Incidence rates of cervical cancer have decreased. Document: Women with persistent HPV infection remained at high risk for grade 2 or 3 lesions or cancer after referral for colposcopy. Relevant:
Query: Incidence rates of cervical cancer have decreased. Document: CONCLUSIONS The addition of an HPV test to the Pap test to screen women in their mid-30s for cervical cancer reduces the incidence of grade 2 or 3 cervical intraepithelial neoplasia or cancer detected by subsequent screening examinations. Query: Ivermectin is used to treat lymphatic filariasis. Document: Reciprocally, leukocytes impact LEC biology: lymphatic vessel permeability depends on DCs while lymphocytes regulate LEC proliferation during inflammation. Relevant:
Query: Ivermectin is used to treat lymphatic filariasis. Document: Altogether, these novel results provide important insights on intimate connections between LECs and leukocytes that contribute to the understanding of immune responses. Relevant:
