Query: Ivermectin is used to treat lymphatic filariasis. Document: The inner lining of these networks is formed by a single layer of endothelial cells, which is specialized according to the needs of the tissue that it supplies. Relevant:
Query: Ivermectin is used to treat lymphatic filariasis. Document: Whereas the general mechanisms of blood and lymphatic vessel development are being defined with increasing molecular precision, studies of the processes of endothelial specialization remain mostly descriptive. Relevant:

Relevant:
Query: Ivermectin is used to treat onchocerciasis. Document: OBJECTIVE To estimate the cost-effectiveness of various 10-year ASCVD risk thresholds that could be used in the ACC/AHA cholesterol treatment guidelines. Relevant:
Query: Ivermectin is used to treat onchocerciasis. Document: DESIGN, SETTING, AND PARTICIPANTS Microsimulation model, including lifetime time horizon, US societal perspective, 3% discount rate for costs, and health outcomes. Relevant:
Query: Ivermectin is used to treat onchocerciasis. Document: In the model, hypothetical individuals from a representative US population aged 40 to 75 years received statin treatment, experienced ASCVD events, and died from ASCVD-related or non-ASCVD-related causes based on ASCVD natural history and statin treatment parameters. Relevant:
Query: Ivermectin is used to treat onchocerciasis. Document: Data sources for model parameters included National Health and Nutrition Examination Surveys, large clinical trials and meta-analyses for statin benefits and treatment, and other published sources. Relevant:
Query: Ivermectin is used to treat onchocerciasis. Document: MAIN OUTCOMES AND MEASURES Estimated ASCVD events prevented and incremental costs per quality-adjusted life-year (QALY) gained. Relevant:
Query: Ivermectin is used to treat onchocerciasis. Document: RESULTS In the base-case scenario, the current ASCVD threshold of 7.5% or higher, which was estimated to be associated with 48% of adults treated with statins, had an incremental cost-effectiveness ratio (ICER) of $37,000/QALY compared with a 10% or higher threshold. Relevant:
Query: Ivermectin is used to treat onchocerciasis. Document: More lenient ASCVD thresholds of 4.0% or higher (61% of adults treated) and 3.0% or higher (67% of adults treated) had ICERs of $81,000/QALY and $140,000/QALY, respectively. Relevant:
Query: Ivermectin is used to treat onchocerciasis. Document: Shifting from a 7.5% or higher ASCVD risk threshold to a 3.0% or higher ASCVD risk threshold was estimated to be associated with an additional 161,560 cardiovascular disease events averted. Relevant:
Query: Ivermectin is used to treat onchocerciasis. Document: Cost-effectiveness results were sensitive to changes in the disutility associated with taking a pill daily, statin price, and the risk of statin-induced diabetes. Relevant:

Query: LDL cholesterol has no involvement in the development of cardiovascular disease. Document: The second genome screen found a third statistically associated SNP at the same locus (rs646776 [p=4.3x10(-9)]). Relevant:
Query: LDL cholesterol has no involvement in the development of cardiovascular disease. Document: Meta-analysis of data from all studies showed an association of SNPs rs599839 (combined p=1.2x10(-33)) and rs646776 (p=4.8x10(-20)) with LDL-cholesterol concentrations. Relevant:
Query: LDL cholesterol has no involvement in the development of cardiovascular disease. Document: SNPs rs599839 and rs646776 both explained around 1% of the variation in circulating LDL-cholesterol concentrations and were associated with about 15% of an SD change in LDL cholesterol per allele, assuming an SD of 1 mmol/L. Query: Leuko-increased blood increases infectious complications in red blood cell transfusion. Document: OBJECTIVE The effects of hydroxyethyl starch on bleeding after cardiopulmonary bypass were determined. Relevant:
Query: Leuko-increased blood increases infectious complications in red blood cell transfusion. Document: METHODS A meta-analysis was performed of postoperative blood loss in randomized clinical trials of hydroxyethyl starch versus albumin for fluid management in adult cardiopulmonary bypass surgery. Relevant:
Query: Leuko-increased blood increases infectious complications in red blood cell transfusion. Document: Impacts of hydroxyethyl starch molecular weight and molar substitution were assessed. Relevant:
Query: Leuko-increased blood increases infectious complications in red blood cell transfusion. Document: Randomized trials directly comparing different hydroxyethyl starch solutions were also included. Relevant:
Query: Leuko-increased blood increases infectious complications in red blood cell transfusion. Document: RESULTS Eighteen trials with 970 total patients were included. Relevant:
Query: Leuko-increased blood increases infectious complications in red blood cell transfusion. Document: Compared with albumin, hydroxyethyl starch increased postoperative blood loss by 33.3% of a pooled SD (95% confidence interval, 18.2%-48.3%; P < .001). Relevant:
Query: Leuko-increased blood increases infectious complications in red blood cell transfusion. Document: Risk of reoperation for bleeding was more than doubled by hydroxyethyl starch (relative risk, 2.24; 95% confidence interval, 1.14-4.40; P = .020). Relevant:
Query: Leuko-increased blood increases infectious complications in red blood cell transfusion. Document: Hydroxyethyl starch increased transfusion of red blood cells by 28.4% of a pooled SD (95% confidence interval, 12.2%-44.6%; P < .001), of fresh-frozen plasma by 30.6% (95% confidence interval, 8.0%-53.1%; P = .008), and of platelets by 29.8% (95% confidence interval, 3.4%-56.2%; P = .027). Relevant:
Query: Leuko-increased blood increases infectious complications in red blood cell transfusion. Document: None of these effects differed significantly between hydroxyethyl starch 450/0.7 and 200/0.5. Relevant:
Query: Leuko-increased blood increases infectious complications in red blood cell transfusion. Document: Insufficient data were available for hydroxyethyl starch 130/0.4 versus albumin; however, no significant differences were detected in head-to-head comparisons of hydroxyethyl starch 130/0.4 with 200/0.5. Relevant:
Query: Leuko-increased blood increases infectious complications in red blood cell transfusion. Document: Albumin improved hemodynamics. Relevant:
Query: Leuko-increased blood increases infectious complications in red blood cell transfusion. Document: There were no differences in fluid balance, ventilator time, intensive care unit stay, or mortality. Relevant:
Query: Leuko-increased blood increases infectious complications in red blood cell transfusion. Document: CONCLUSIONS Hydroxyethyl starch increased blood loss, reoperation for bleeding, and blood product transfusion after cardiopulmonary bypass. Relevant:
Query: Leuko-increased blood increases infectious complications in red blood cell transfusion. Document: There was no evidence that these risks could be mitigated by lower molecular weight and substitution. Relevant:
Query: Leuko-increased blood increases infectious complications in red blood cell transfusion. Document: CONTEXT A number of countries have implemented a policy of universal leukoreduction of their blood supply, but the potential role of leukoreduction in decreasing postoperative mortality and infection is unclear. Relevant:
Query: Leuko-increased blood increases infectious complications in red blood cell transfusion. Document: OBJECTIVE To evaluate clinical outcomes following adoption of a national universal prestorage leukoreduction program for blood transfusions. Relevant:
Query: Leuko-increased blood increases infectious complications in red blood cell transfusion. Document: DESIGN, SETTING, AND POPULATION Retrospective before-and-after cohort study conducted from August 1998 to August 2000 in 23 academic and community hospitals throughout Canada, enrolling 14 786 patients who received red blood cell transfusions following cardiac surgery or repair of hip fracture, or who required intensive care following a surgical intervention or multiple trauma. Relevant:
Query: Leuko-increased blood increases infectious complications in red blood cell transfusion. Document: INTERVENTION Universal prestorage leukoreduction program introduced by 2 Canadian blood agencies. Relevant:
Query: Leuko-increased blood increases infectious complications in red blood cell transfusion. Document: A total of 6982 patients were enrolled during the control period and 7804 patients were enrolled following prestorage leukoreduction. Relevant:
Query: Leuko-increased blood increases infectious complications in red blood cell transfusion. Document: MAIN OUTCOME MEASURES All-cause in-hospital mortality and serious nosocomial infections (pneumonia, bacteremia, septic shock, all surgical site infections) occurring after first transfusion and at least 2 days after index procedure or intensive care unit admission. Relevant:
Query: Leuko-increased blood increases infectious complications in red blood cell transfusion. Document: Secondary outcomes included rates of posttransfusion fever and antibiotic use. Relevant:
Query: Leuko-increased blood increases infectious complications in red blood cell transfusion. Document: RESULTS Unadjusted in-hospital mortality rates were significantly lower following the introduction of leukoreduction compared with the control period (6.19% vs 7.03%, respectively; P =.04). Relevant:
Query: Leuko-increased blood increases infectious complications in red blood cell transfusion. Document: Compared with the control period, the adjusted odds of death following leukoreduction were reduced (odds ratio [OR], 0.87; 95% confidence interval [CI], 0.75-0.99), but serious nosocomial infections did not decrease (adjusted OR, 0.97; 95% CI, 0.87-1.09). Relevant:
Query: Leuko-increased blood increases infectious complications in red blood cell transfusion. Document: The frequency of posttransfusion fevers decreased significantly following leukoreduction (adjusted OR, 0.86; 95% CI, 0.79-0.94), as did antibiotic use (adjusted OR, 0.90; 95% CI, 0.82-0.99). Relevant:
Query: Leuko-increased blood increases infectious complications in red blood cell transfusion. Document: CONCLUSION A national universal leukoreduction program is potentially associated with decreased mortality as well as decreased fever episodes and antibiotic use after red blood cell transfusion in high-risk patients. Relevant:

Document: BACKGROUND The occurrence of transfusion transmissions of variant Creutzfeldt-Jakob disease (CJD) cases has reawakened attention to the possible similar risk posed by other forms of CJD. Relevant:
Query: Leuko-increased blood increases infectious complications in red blood cell transfusion. Document: STUDY DESIGN AND METHODS CJD with a definite or probable diagnosis (sporadic CJD, n = 741; genetic CJD, n = 175) and no-CJD patients with definite alternative diagnosis (n = 482) with available blood transfusion history were included in the study. Relevant:
Query: Leuko-increased blood increases infectious complications in red blood cell transfusion. Document: The risk of exposure to blood transfusion occurring more than 10 years before disease onset and for some possible confounding factors was evaluated by calculating crude odds ratios (ORs). Relevant:
Query: Leuko-increased blood increases infectious complications in red blood cell transfusion. Document: Variables with significant ORs in univariate analyses were included in multivariate logistic regression analyses. Relevant:
Query: Leuko-increased blood increases infectious complications in red blood cell transfusion. Document: RESULTS In the univariate model, blood transfusion occurring more than 10 years before clinical onset is 4.1-fold more frequent in sporadic CJD than in other neurologic disorders. Relevant:
Query: Leuko-increased blood increases infectious complications in red blood cell transfusion. Document: This significance is lost when the 10-year lag time was not considered. Relevant:
Query: Leuko-increased blood increases infectious complications in red blood cell transfusion. Document: Multivariate analyses show that the risk of developing sporadic CJD after transfusion increases (OR, 5.05) after adjusting for possible confounding factors. Relevant:
Query: Leuko-increased blood increases infectious complications in red blood cell transfusion. Document: Analysis conducted on patients with genetic CJD did not reveal any significant risk factor associated with transfusion. Relevant:
Query: Leuko-increased blood increases infectious complications in red blood cell transfusion. Document: CONCLUSION This is the first case-control study showing a significant risk of transfusion occurring more than 10 years before clinical onset in sporadic CJD patients. Relevant:
Query: Leuko-increased blood increases infectious complications in red blood cell transfusion. Document: It remains questionable whether the significance of these data is biologically plausible or the consequence of biases in the design of the study, but they counterbalance previous epidemiologic negative reports that might have overestimated the assessment of blood safety in sporadic CJD. Query: Localization of PIN1 in the Arabidopsis embryo does not require VPS9a Document: These gradients are mediated by cellular efflux requiring asymmetrically localized PIN proteins, which represent a functionally redundant network for auxin distribution in both aerial and underground organs. Document: CONCLUSIONS The key messages of these modelling results for policy makers were: high coverage with ACT treatment can produce a long-term reduction in malaria whereas the impact of MDA is generally only short-term; primaquine enhances the effect of ACT in eliminating malaria and reduces the increase in proportion of artemisinin resistant infections; parasite prevalence is a better surveillance measure for elimination programmes than numbers of symptomatic cases; combinations of interventions are most effective and sustained efforts are crucial for successful elimination. Query: Radioiodine treatment of non-toxic multinodular goitre reduces thyroid volume. Document: Here we show that the SUMO ligase and the chromosome disjunction functions of Mms21 depend on its docking to an intact and active Smc5/6 complex, indicating that the Smc5/6-Mms21 complex operates as a large SUMO ligase in vivo. Relevant:

Query: Statins decrease blood cholesterol. Document: Statins are potent inhibitors of cholesterol biosynthesis. Relevant:
Query: Statins decrease blood cholesterol. Document: In clinical trials, statins are beneficial in the primary and secondary prevention of coronary heart disease. Relevant:
Query: Statins decrease blood cholesterol. Document: However, the overall benefits observed with statins appear to be greater than what might be expected from changes in lipid levels alone, suggesting effects beyond cholesterol lowering. Relevant:
Query: Statins decrease blood cholesterol. Document: Indeed, recent studies indicate that some of the cholesterol-independent or "pleiotropic" effects of statins involve improving endothelial function, enhancing the stability of atherosclerotic plaques, decreasing oxidative stress and inflammation, and inhibiting the thrombogenic response. Relevant:
Query: Statins decrease blood cholesterol. Document: Furthermore, statins have beneficial extrahepatic effects on the immune system, CNS, and bone. Relevant:
Query: Statins decrease blood cholesterol. Document: Many of these pleiotropic effects are mediated by inhibition of isoprenoids, which serve as lipid attachments for intracellular signaling molecules. Relevant:
Query: Statins decrease blood cholesterol. Document: In particular, inhibition of small GTP-binding proteins, Rho, Ras, and Rac, whose proper membrane localization and function are dependent on isoprenylation, may play an important role in mediating the pleiotropic effects of statins. Relevant:
Query: Statins decrease blood cholesterol. Document: CONTEXT Gallstone disease is a leading cause of morbidity in western countries and carries a high economic burden. Relevant:
Query: Statins decrease blood cholesterol. Document: Statins decrease hepatic cholesterol biosynthesis and may therefore lower the risk of cholesterol gallstones by reducing the cholesterol concentration in the bile. Relevant:
Query: Statins decrease blood cholesterol. Document: Data on this association in humans are scarce. Relevant:
Query: Statins decrease blood cholesterol. Document: OBJECTIVE To study the association between the use of statins, fibrates, or other lipid-lowering agents and the risk of incident gallstone disease followed by cholecystectomy. Relevant:
Query: Statins decrease blood cholesterol. Document: DESIGN, SETTING, AND PARTICIPANTS Case-control analysis using the UK-based General Practice Research Database. Relevant:
Query: Statins decrease blood cholesterol. Document: Incident patients between 1994 and 2008 and 4 controls per each patient were identified and matched on age, sex, general practice, calendar time, and years of history in the database. Relevant:
Query: Statins decrease blood cholesterol. Document: The study population was 76% women and the mean (SD) age was 53.4 (15.0) years at the index date. Relevant:
Query: Statins decrease blood cholesterol. Document: Conditional logistic regression was used to estimate the odds ratio (OR) of developing gallstones followed by cholecystectomy in relation to exposure to lipid-lowering agents, stratified by exposure timing and duration. Relevant:
Query: Statins decrease blood cholesterol. Document: The ORs and 95% confidence intervals (CIs) were adjusted for smoking, body mass index, ischemic heart disease, stroke, and estrogen use. Relevant:
Query: Statins decrease blood cholesterol. Document: MAIN OUTCOME MEASURE The adjusted OR (AOR) for developing gallstone disease followed by cholecystectomy in relation to exposure to lipid-lowering agents. Relevant:
Query: Statins decrease blood cholesterol. Document: RESULTS A total of 27,035 patients with cholecystectomy and 106,531 matched controls were identified, including 2396 patients and 8868 controls who had statin use. Relevant:
Query: Statins decrease blood cholesterol. Document: Compared with nonuse, current statin use (last prescription recorded within 90 days before the first-time diagnosis of the disease) was 1.0% for patients and 0.8% for controls (AOR, 1.10; 95% CI, 0.95-1.27) for 1 to 4 prescriptions; 2.6% vs 2.4% (AOR, 0.85; 95% CI, 0.77-0.93) for 5 to 19 prescriptions, and 3.2% vs 3.7% (AOR, 0.64; 95% CI, 0.59-0.70) for 20 or more prescriptions. Relevant:
Query: Statins decrease blood cholesterol. Document: The AORs for current use of statins defined as 20 or more prescriptions were similar (around 0.6) across age, sex, and body mass index categories, and across the statin class. Relevant:
Query: Statins decrease blood cholesterol. Document: CONCLUSION Long-term use of statins was associated with a decreased risk of gallstones followed by cholecystectomy. Relevant:
Query: Statins decrease blood cholesterol. Document: IMPORTANCE The American College of Cardiology and the American Heart Association (ACC/AHA) cholesterol treatment guidelines have wide-scale implications for treating adults without history of atherosclerotic cardiovascular disease (ASCVD) with statins. Relevant:
Query: Statins decrease blood cholesterol. Document: OBJECTIVE To estimate the cost-effectiveness of various 10-year ASCVD risk thresholds that could be used in the ACC/AHA cholesterol treatment guidelines. Relevant:
Query: Statins decrease blood cholesterol. Document: DESIGN, SETTING, AND PARTICIPANTS Microsimulation model, including lifetime time horizon, US societal perspective, 3% discount rate for costs, and health outcomes. Relevant:
Query: Statins decrease blood cholesterol. Document: In the model, hypothetical individuals from a representative US population aged 40 to 75 years received statin treatment, experienced ASCVD events, and died from ASCVD-related or non-ASCVD-related causes based on ASCVD natural history and statin treatment parameters. Relevant:
Query: Statins decrease blood cholesterol. Document: Data sources for model parameters included National Health and Nutrition Examination Surveys, large clinical trials and meta-analyses for statin benefits and treatment, and other published sources. Relevant:
Query: Statins decrease blood cholesterol. Document: MAIN OUTCOMES AND MEASURES Estimated ASCVD events prevented and incremental costs per quality-adjusted life-year (QALY) gained. Relevant:
Query: Statins decrease blood cholesterol. Document: RESULTS In the base-case scenario, the current ASCVD threshold of 7.5% or higher, which was estimated to be associated with 48% of adults treated with statins, had an incremental cost-effectiveness ratio (ICER) of $37,000/QALY compared with a 10% or higher threshold. Relevant:
Query: Statins decrease blood cholesterol. Document: More lenient ASCVD thresholds of 4.0% or higher (61% of adults treated) and 3.0% or higher (67% of adults treated) had ICERs of $81,000/QALY and $140,000/QALY, respectively. Relevant:
Query: Statins decrease blood cholesterol. Document: Shifting from a 7.5% or higher ASCVD risk threshold to a 3.0% or higher ASCVD risk threshold was estimated to be associated with an additional 161,560 cardiovascular disease events averted. Relevant:
Query: Statins decrease blood cholesterol. Document: Cost-effectiveness results were sensitive to changes in the disutility associated with taking a pill daily, statin price, and the risk of statin-induced diabetes. Relevant:
Query: Statins decrease blood cholesterol. Document: In probabilistic sensitivity analysis, there was a higher than 93% chance that the optimal ASCVD threshold was 5.0% or lower using a cost-effectiveness threshold of $100,000/QALY. Relevant:
Query: Statins decrease blood cholesterol. Document: CONCLUSIONS AND RELEVANCE In this microsimulation model of US adults aged 45 to 75 years [corrected], the current 10-year ASCVD risk threshold (≥7.5% risk threshold) used in the ACC/AHA cholesterol treatment guidelines has an acceptable cost-effectiveness profile (ICER, $37,000/QALY), but more lenient ASCVD thresholds would be optimal using cost-effectiveness thresholds of $100,000/QALY (≥4.0% risk threshold) or $150,000/QALY (≥3.0% risk threshold). Relevant:
Query: Statins decrease blood cholesterol. Document: The optimal ASCVD threshold was sensitive to patient preferences for taking a pill daily, changes to statin price, and the risk of statin-induced diabetes. Relevant:

Query: Stroke patients with prior use of direct oral anticoagulants have a lower risk of in-hospital mortality than stroke patients with prior use of warfarin. Document: It is now estimated that there are more than 700 000 incident strokes annually and 4.4 million stroke survivors.1 2 The economic burden of stroke was estimated by the American Heart Association to be $51 billion (direct and indirect costs) in 1999.3 Despite the advent of treatment of selected patients with acute ischemic stroke with tissue plasminogen activator and the promise of other experimental therapies, the best approach to reducing the burden of stroke remains prevention.4 5 High-risk or stroke-prone individuals can be identified and targeted for specific interventions.6 This is important because epidemiological data suggest a substantial leveling off of prior declines in stroke-related mortality and a possible increase in stroke incidence.7 8   The Stroke Council of the American Heart Association formed an ad hoc writing group to provide a clear and concise overview of the evidence regarding various established and potential stroke risk factors. Relevant:

Document: Levels of Evidence and Grading of Recommendations    As given in Tables 2 through 4⇓⇓⇓, risk factors or risk markers for a first stroke were classified according to potential for modification (nonmodifiable, modifiable, or potentially modifiable) and strength of evidence (well documented, less well documented).5 The tables give the estimated prevalence, population attributable risk, relative risk, and risk reduction with treatment for each factor when known. Query: Taking 400mg of α-tocopheryl acetate helps to prevent prostate cancer. Document: CONTEXT Many individuals take vitamins in the hopes of preventing chronic diseases such as cancer, and vitamins E and C are among the most common individual supplements. Relevant:
Query: Taking 400mg of α-tocopheryl acetate helps to prevent prostate cancer. Document: A large-scale randomized trial suggested that vitamin E may reduce risk of prostate cancer; however, few trials have been powered to address this relationship. Relevant:
Query: Taking 400mg of α-tocopheryl acetate helps to prevent prostate cancer. Document: No previous trial in men at usual risk has examined vitamin C alone in the prevention of cancer. Relevant:
Query: Taking 400mg of α-tocopheryl acetate helps to prevent prostate cancer. Document: OBJECTIVE To evaluate whether long-term vitamin E or C supplementation decreases risk of prostate and total cancer events among men. Relevant:
Query: Taking 400mg of α-tocopheryl acetate helps to prevent prostate cancer. Document: DESIGN, SETTING, AND PARTICIPANTS The Physicians' Health Study II is a randomized, double-blind, placebo-controlled factorial trial of vitamins E and C that began in 1997 and continued until its scheduled completion on August 31, 2007. Relevant:
Query: Taking 400mg of α-tocopheryl acetate helps to prevent prostate cancer. Document: A total of 14,641 male physicians in the United States initially aged 50 years or older, including 1307 men with a history of prior cancer at randomization, were enrolled. Relevant:
Query: Taking 400mg of α-tocopheryl acetate helps to prevent prostate cancer. Document: INTERVENTION Individual supplements of 400 IU of vitamin E every other day and 500 mg of vitamin C daily. Relevant:
Query: Taking 400mg of α-tocopheryl acetate helps to prevent prostate cancer. Document: MAIN OUTCOME MEASURES Prostate and total cancer. Relevant:
Query: Taking 400mg of α-tocopheryl acetate helps to prevent prostate cancer. Document: RESULTS During a mean follow-up of 8.0 years, there were 1008 confirmed incident cases of prostate cancer and 1943 total cancers. Relevant:
Query: Taking 400mg of α-tocopheryl acetate helps to prevent prostate cancer. Document: Compared with placebo, vitamin E had no effect on the incidence of prostate cancer (active and placebo vitamin E groups, 9.1 and 9.5 events per 1000 person-years; hazard ratio [HR], 0.97; 95% confidence interval [CI], 0.85-1.09; P = .58) or total cancer (active and placebo vitamin E groups, 17.8 and 17.3 cases per 1000 person-years; HR, 1.04; 95% CI, 0.95-1.13; P = .41). Relevant:
Query: Taking 400mg of α-tocopheryl acetate helps to prevent prostate cancer. Document: There was also no significant effect of vitamin C on total cancer (active and placebo vitamin C groups, 17.6 and 17.5 events per 1000 person-years; HR, 1.01; 95% CI, 0.92-1.10; P = .86) or prostate cancer (active and placebo vitamin C groups, 9.4 and 9.2 cases per 1000 person-years; HR, 1.02; 95% CI, 0.90-1.15; P = .80). Relevant:
Query: Taking 400mg of α-tocopheryl acetate helps to prevent prostate cancer. Document: Neither vitamin E nor vitamin C had a significant effect on colorectal, lung, or other site-specific cancers. Relevant:
Query: Taking 400mg of α-tocopheryl acetate helps to prevent prostate cancer. Document: Adjustment for adherence and exclusion of the first 4 or 6 years of follow-up did not alter the results. Relevant:
Query: Taking 400mg of α-tocopheryl acetate helps to prevent prostate cancer. Document: Stratification by various cancer risk factors demonstrated no significant modification of the effect of vitamin E on prostate cancer risk or either agent on total cancer risk. Relevant:
Query: Taking 400mg of α-tocopheryl acetate helps to prevent prostate cancer. Document: CONCLUSIONS In this large, long-term trial of male physicians, neither vitamin E nor C supplementation reduced the risk of prostate or total cancer. Relevant:
Query: Taking 400mg of α-tocopheryl acetate helps to prevent prostate cancer. Document: These data provide no support for the use of these supplements for the prevention of cancer in middle-aged and older men. Relevant:
Query: Taking 400mg of α-tocopheryl acetate helps to prevent prostate cancer. Document: TRIAL REGISTRATION clinicaltrials.gov Identifier: NCT00270647. Relevant:
Query: Taking 400mg of α-tocopheryl acetate helps to prevent prostate cancer. Document: Metabolic pathway reprogramming is a hallmark of cancer cell growth and survival and supports the anabolic and energetic demands of these rapidly dividing cells. Relevant:

Relevant:

Relevant:

Relevant:

Relevant:

Query: Taxation of sugar-sweetened beverages had no effect on the incidence rate of type II diabetes in India. Document: RESULTS Those with stable consumption patterns had no difference in weight gain, but weight gain over a 4-year period was highest among women who increased their sugar-sweetened soft drink consumption from 1 or fewer drinks per week to 1 or more drinks per day (multivariate-adjusted means, 4.69 kg for 1991 to 1995 and 4.20 kg for 1995 to 1999) and was smallest among women who decreased their intake (1.34 and 0.15 kg for the 2 periods, respectively) after adjusting for lifestyle and dietary confounders. Query: Teaching hospitals do not provide better care than non-teaching hospitals. Document: Background  Extensive debate exists in the healthcare community over whether outcomes of medical care at teaching hospitals and other healthcare units are better or worse than those at the respective nonteaching ones. Relevant:
Query: Teaching hospitals do not provide better care than non-teaching hospitals. Document: Thus, our goal was to systematically evaluate the evidence pertaining to this question. Relevant:
Query: Teaching hospitals do not provide better care than non-teaching hospitals. Document: Methods and Findings  We reviewed all studies that compared teaching versus nonteaching healthcare structures for mortality or any other patient outcome, regardless of health condition. Relevant:
Query: Teaching hospitals do not provide better care than non-teaching hospitals. Document: Studies were retrieved from PubMed, contact with experts, and literature cross-referencing. Relevant:
Query: Teaching hospitals do not provide better care than non-teaching hospitals. Document: Data were extracted on setting, patients, data sources, author affiliations, definition of compared groups, types of diagnoses considered, adjusting covariates, and estimates of effect for mortality and for each other outcome. Relevant:
Query: Teaching hospitals do not provide better care than non-teaching hospitals. Document: Overall, 132 eligible studies were identified, including 93 on mortality and 61 on other eligible outcomes (22 addressed both). Relevant:
Query: Teaching hospitals do not provide better care than non-teaching hospitals. Document: Synthesis of the available adjusted estimates on mortality yielded a summary relative risk of 0.96 (95% confidence interval [CI], 0.93–1.00) for teaching versus nonteaching healthcare structures and 1.04 (95% CI, 0.99–1.10) for minor teaching versus nonteaching ones. Relevant:
Query: Teaching hospitals do not provide better care than non-teaching hospitals. Document: There was considerable heterogeneity between studies (I2 = 72% for the main analysis). Relevant:
Query: Teaching hospitals do not provide better care than non-teaching hospitals. Document: Results were similar in studies using clinical and those using administrative databases. Relevant:
Query: Teaching hospitals do not provide better care than non-teaching hospitals. Document: No differences were seen in the 14 studies fully adjusting for volume/experience, severity, and comorbidity (relative risk 1.01). Relevant:
Query: Teaching hospitals do not provide better care than non-teaching hospitals. Document: Smaller studies did not differ in their results from larger studies. Relevant:
Query: Teaching hospitals do not provide better care than non-teaching hospitals. Document: Differences were seen for some diagnoses (e.g., significantly better survival for breast cancer and cerebrovascular accidents in teaching hospitals and significantly better survival from cholecystectomy in nonteaching hospitals), but these were small in magnitude. Relevant:
Query: Teaching hospitals do not provide better care than non-teaching hospitals. Document: Other outcomes were diverse, but typically teaching healthcare structures did not do better than nonteaching ones. Relevant:
Query: Teaching hospitals do not provide better care than non-teaching hospitals. Document: Conclusions  The available data are limited by their nonrandomized design, but overall they do not suggest that a healthcare facility's teaching status on its own markedly improves or worsens patient outcomes. Relevant:
Query: Teaching hospitals do not provide better care than non-teaching hospitals. Document: Differences for specific diseases cannot be excluded, but are likely to be small. Relevant:
Query: Teaching hospitals do not provide better care than non-teaching hospitals. Query: Teaching hospitals do not provide better care than non-teaching hospitals. Document: Subjects: 1134 admissions to the intensive care unit over a 3-year period, of whom 476 (42%) followed elective surgery. Relevant:

Query: Teaching hospitals do not provide better care than non-teaching hospitals. Document: Results: Crude hospital mortality fell from 28% before the changes to 20% afterwards (P=0.01). Relevant:
Query: Teaching hospitals do not provide better care than non-teaching hospitals. Document: With correction for case-mix factors, the probability of death after the changes was reduced by almost half (OR 0.51; CI 0.32, 0.82, P=0.005). Relevant:
Query: Teaching hospitals do not provide better care than non-teaching hospitals. Document: Conclusion: A "closed" format of organisation of the delivery of care may result in improved outcomes for patients admitted to intensive care units. Relevant:

Query: Teaching hospitals do not provide better care than non-teaching hospitals. Document: SETTING 10 wards in a teaching and non-teaching hospital in the United Kingdom. Relevant:
Query: Teaching hospitals do not provide better care than non-teaching hospitals. Document: MAIN OUTCOME MEASURES Number, type, and clinical importance of errors. Relevant:
Query: Teaching hospitals do not provide better care than non-teaching hospitals. Document: RESULTS 249 errors were identified. Relevant:
Query: Teaching hospitals do not provide better care than non-teaching hospitals. Document: At least one error occurred in 212 out of 430 intravenous drug doses (49%, 95% confidence interval 45% to 54%). Relevant:
Query: Teaching hospitals do not provide better care than non-teaching hospitals. Document: Three doses (1%) had potentially severe errors, 126 (29%) potentially moderate errors, and 83 (19%) potentially minor errors. Relevant:
Query: Teaching hospitals do not provide better care than non-teaching hospitals. Document: Most errors occurred when giving bolus doses or making up drugs that required multiple step preparation. Relevant:
Query: Teaching hospitals do not provide better care than non-teaching hospitals. Document: CONCLUSIONS The rate of intravenous drug errors was high. Relevant:
Query: Teaching hospitals do not provide better care than non-teaching hospitals. Document: Although most errors would cause only short term adverse effects, a few could have been serious. Relevant:
Query: Teaching hospitals do not provide better care than non-teaching hospitals. Document: A combination of reducing the amount of preparation on the ward, training, and technology to administer slow bolus doses would probably have the greatest effect on error rates. Relevant:

Query: There is an inverse relationship between hip fractures and statin use. Document: CONTEXT Recent animal studies have found that 3-hydroxy-3-methylglutaryl coenzyme A (HMG-CoA) lipid-lowering drugs (statins) substantially increase bone formation, but whether statin use in humans results in clinically meaningful bone formation or a reduction in the risk of osteoporotic fractures is not known. Relevant:
Query: There is an inverse relationship between hip fractures and statin use. Document: OBJECTIVE To determine whether the use of statins is associated with reduced hip fracture risk. Relevant:
Query: There is an inverse relationship between hip fractures and statin use. Document: DESIGN Case-control study. Relevant:
Query: There is an inverse relationship between hip fractures and statin use. Document: SETTING AND PATIENTS A total of 6110 New Jersey residents aged 65 years or older and enrolled in Medicare and either Medicaid or the Pharmacy Assistance for the Aged and Disabled program. Relevant:
Query: There is an inverse relationship between hip fractures and statin use. Document: Case patients (n=1222) underwent surgical repair of a hip fracture in 1994. Relevant:
Query: There is an inverse relationship between hip fractures and statin use. Document: Control patients (n=4888) were identified at a ratio of 4:1 and frequency-matched to case patients for age and sex. Relevant:
Query: There is an inverse relationship between hip fractures and statin use. Document: MAIN OUTCOME MEASURE Adjusted odds ratio (OR) of hip fracture by statin use in the 180 days and 3 years prior to the index date (the earliest date of admission for surgery), adjusted for demographic and clinical characteristics and health care utilization. Relevant:
Query: There is an inverse relationship between hip fractures and statin use. Document: RESULTS Use of statins in either the prior 180 days (adjusted OR, 0.50; 95% confidence interval [CI], 0.33-0.76) or prior 3 years (adjusted OR, 0.57; 95% CI, 0.40-0.82) was associated with a significant reduction in the risk of hip fracture, even after controlling for variables such as race, insurance status, psychoactive medications, estrogen and thiazide use, ischemic heart disease, cancer, and diabetes mellitus. Relevant:
Query: There is an inverse relationship between hip fractures and statin use. Document: No significant relationship was observed between use of nonstatin lipid-lowering agents and hip fracture risk. Relevant:
Query: There is an inverse relationship between hip fractures and statin use. Document: Clear relationships were observed between the degree of reduction in hip fracture risk and the extent of statin use; there was no evidence of such relationships with nonstatin lipid-lowering agents. Relevant:
Query: There is an inverse relationship between hip fractures and statin use. Document: After adjusting for extent of statin use in the prior 3 years, current use (on the index date) was associated with a 71% reduction in risk (adjusted OR, 0.29; 95% CI, 0.10-0.81). Relevant:
Query: There is an inverse relationship between hip fractures and statin use. Document: The relationship between statin use and hip fracture risk persisted after controlling for variables such as the number of medications, the Charlson comorbidity index score, and hospitalization or nursing home stay in the last 180 days, as well as after excluding patients who were in a nursing home prior to their index date or who died in the year after their index date. Query: UCB T cells maintain high TCR diversity after transplantation. Document: Analysis of duplicate blood samples confirmed that we accurately determined the frequency of individual TCRs. Relevant:
Query: UCB T cells maintain high TCR diversity after transplantation. Document: After 6 months, cord blood-graft recipients approximated the TCR diversity of healthy individuals, whereas recipients of T cell-depleted peripheral-blood stem cell grafts had 28-fold and 14-fold lower CD4(+) and CD8(+) T cell diversities, respectively. Relevant:
Query: UCB T cells maintain high TCR diversity after transplantation. Document: After 12 months, these deficiencies had improved for the CD4(+) but not the CD8(+) T cell compartment. Relevant:

Query: Ultrasound guidance significantly raises the number of traumatic procedures when attempting needle insertion. Document: REVIEW METHODS Randomised trials that compared ultrasound imaging with standard methods (no imaging) in the performance of a lumbar puncture or epidural catheterisation were identified. Relevant:
Query: Ultrasound guidance significantly raises the number of traumatic procedures when attempting needle insertion. Document: RESULTS 14 studies with a total of 1334 patients were included (674 patients assigned to the ultrasound group, 660 to the control group). Relevant:
Query: Ultrasound guidance significantly raises the number of traumatic procedures when attempting needle insertion. Document: Five studies evaluated lumbar punctures and nine evaluated epidural catheterisations. Relevant:
Query: Ultrasound guidance significantly raises the number of traumatic procedures when attempting needle insertion. Document: Six of 624 procedures conducted in the ultrasound group failed; 44 of 610 procedures in the control group failed. Relevant:
Query: Ultrasound guidance significantly raises the number of traumatic procedures when attempting needle insertion. Document: Ultrasound imaging reduced the risk of failed procedures (risk ratio 0.21 (95% confidence interval 0.10 to 0.43), P<0.001). Relevant:

Document: Risk reduction was similar when subgroup analysis was performed for lumbar punctures (risk ratio 0.19 (0.07 to 0.56), P=0.002) or epidural catheterisations (0.23 (0.09 to 0.60), P=0.003). Query: Women with a higher birth weight are more likely to develop breast cancer later in life. Document: RESULTS We found that heavier birth weights were associated with increased breast cancer risk, with studies involving five categories of birth weight identifying odds ratios (ORs) of 1.24 (95% confidence interval [CI] 1.04 to 1.48) for 4,000 g or more and 1.15 (95% CI 1.04 to 1.26) for 3,500 g to 3,999 g, relative to a birth weight of 2,500 to 2,599 g. Query: aPKCz causes tumour enhancement by affecting glutamine metabolism. Document: Whereas most cells use glutamate dehydrogenase (GLUD1) to convert glutamine-derived glutamate into α-ketoglutarate in the mitochondria to fuel the tricarboxylic acid cycle, PDAC relies on a distinct pathway in which glutamine-derived aspartate is transported into the cytoplasm where it can be converted into oxaloacetate by aspartate transaminase (GOT1). Relevant:
Query: aPKCz causes tumour enhancement by affecting glutamine metabolism. Document: Subsequently, this oxaloacetate is converted into malate and then pyruvate, ostensibly increasing the NADPH/NADP(+) ratio which can potentially maintain the cellular redox state. Relevant:
Query: aPKCz causes tumour enhancement by affecting glutamine metabolism. Document: Importantly, PDAC cells are strongly dependent on this series of reactions, as glutamine deprivation or genetic inhibition of any enzyme in this pathway leads to an increase in reactive oxygen species and a reduction in reduced glutathione.
